story: Scientists say the rate of Covid- infection throughout the country was halving every eight to nine days during May.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNew research from Imperial College London shows there were on average  positive cases for every , people, with an overall reproduction number of . - lower than previously reported.The R value - or reproduction rate - is the average number of people an infected person spreads the virus to.It can indicate whether the epidemic is getting bigger or smaller - an R rate of above one indicates a growing epidemic, while less than one suggests the outbreak is shrinking.At the peak of Britains coronavirus outbreak, the R rate is thought to have reached three - forcing the country into lockdown, to suppress the spread and flatten the peak.Detailing his roadmap for getting Britain out of lockdown, Boris Johnson said on May  that any measures taken must not risk pushing the R rate above one. It was previously thought that the value had only just reached  at the end of May.This allowed for some restrictions to be eased on June  when some school years ed, outdoor markets reopened and people were allowed to meet up outdoors in groups of six - with social distancing rules in place.R, or R nought, refers to the average number of people that one infected person can expect to pass the coronavirus on to.Scientists use it to predict how far and how fast a disease will spread - and the number can also inform policy decisions about how to contain an outbreak.For example,a virus has an R of three, it means that every sick person will pass the disease on to three other peopleno containment measures are introduced.Its also worth pointing out that the R is a measure of how infectious a disease is, but not how deadly.The latest Government statistics published last week show that the R value is currently between . and  for England, with some regional iations.It is above  in the South West at between . to ., while the South East is in the range of . to ..East Anglia and the North West have also seen similar increases in their R value ranges - from . to . in the previous week to . to .However, the value is down slightly in the Midlands - despite a local outbreak and subsequent lockdown in Leicester - to between . and ..  The figures were published a week after pubs, restaurants, hotels and hairdressers were allowed to reopen.The modelling, by a sub-group of the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , use data such as contacts, hospital admissions, ICU admissions and deaths.It generally takes - weeks for changes in R to be reflected due to the time between infection and needing hospital care.For the new study, published today, researchers tested more than , volunteers aged over five across the country for Covid-.About  per cent of those who tested positive reported no symptoms on the day of the test or the previous week, though they may have developed symptoms later.The report provides an insight into who was infected with the virus between May  and June , comparing geography, age, sex, ethnicity, key worker status and symptoms.Beyond the diminished rate of infection, the research found young adults aged  to  were more likely to test positive than other age groups.People of Asian ethnicity were also more likely to test positive than those of white ethnicity, while people working in care homes were at greater risk of being infected during lockdown than the general population.The report also showed anyone who had recent contact with a known Covid- case was  times more likely to test positive than those with no such contact, emphasising the importance of contact tracing in keeping the spread of the virus under control.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the study is crucial to the countrys ongoing battle with coronavirus.This ambitious testing programme will help us better understand the spread of the virus to date, predict how it may spread in the future and inform our response to the pandemic, he said.It shows the impact our national lockdown efforts have had and demonstrates that we have taken the right actions at the right time.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.As a country we have made great strides towards beating this virus but we mustnt take our foot off the pedal, and such studies will be vital as we continue to fight this virus.The study, which has been upscaled and repeated for June, will now undergo peer review before a final report is published.Plans are currently underway for a title: banksy graffiti rats london tube 7 5m scrubbed off
story: The spray painted series of rodents in carriages were part of a message urging Londoners to wear masks.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesA TfL spokesperson confirmed no one knew Banksy had left work on the Tube until a video emerged yesterday, and so it was dealt with as regular graffiti would be - with cleaners having no clue what they were removing.Banksy, himself masked up, took to the network days ago to daub a carriage with Covid-infected vermin. Joey Syer, Co-founder of MyArtBroker - which has more than  years of experience of art dealing and specialises in Banksys work - believes it could have been worth millions.He told the Sun Online: Its a huge shame and opportunity lost for Londoners that the latest Banksy work has already been removed by the anti-graffiti teams at TFL. Of course, we understand why, and we understand its highly likely whoever removed it was following procedure and had no idea they were destroying a Banksy. Had TFL management known, and had the opportunity to remove and protect the installation we estimate its value as a complete package to be in the region of £.million.Sadiq Khan must be kicking himself, but Banksy has yet again proved his ability to entertain and make a statement with such daring and style.A Transport for London source told the Evening Standard the cleaners had no idea of the signicance of the work, saying: “When we saw the video, we started to look into it and spoke to the cleaners. It started to emerge that they had noticed some sort of ‘rat thing’ a few days ago and cleaned it off, as they should.It comes after Mayor of London Sadiq Khan handed over control of the capitals transport system in a row over cash.The Government gave him a £.bn bailout last month to keep the network afloat after the mayor insisted it was cash-strapped.A TfL spokesperson said: “We appreciate the sentiment of encouraging people to wear face coverings, which the vast majority of customers on our transport network are doing. In this particular case, the work was removed some days ago due to our strict anti-graffiti policy. We’d like to offer Banksy the chance to do a new version of his message for our customers in a suitable location.”They added when graffiti is spotted, the train is pulled out of service and into a depot where cleaners will go on and wipe it off before the train goes back into use, usually on the same day.In a video shared to the artists Instagram, the anonymous graffiti genius is seen entering a carriage in a hazmat suit, face mask and goggles. Its suggested Banksy had disguised himself as one of TFLs deep-cleaners.As commuters look on he paints stencils on train walls and windows and is also filmed getting on and off at ious stops.The message of the masterpieces - a rat spraying gunk and snot across a carriage, another rat frolicking inside a discarded surgical mask and another using PPE as a parachute - is to wear a mask.The artist captioned the post: If you dont mask you dont get.Brits were told by the Government they would need to wear face coverings on public transport back in June, and new measures have since been introduced to enforce the wearing of face coverings in shops in a few weeks time.In the footage, commuters try not to stare as he sprays a tag on the back wall of a Tube carriage, dripping in what looks like infectious-looking slime.Other commuters rush past the street art legend as he heads up the stairs to the next  - his paints cleverly disguised as disinfectant spray gear at his side.The video ends with a shot of the slogan I get lockdown sprayed on a wall at - from the sound of the announcements - Euston Square Station. As Tube doors close in front of it, the message: But I get up again appears as the video plays the  Chumbawumba hit Tubthumping. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: face masks cafe pret matt hancock
story: Matt Hancock said this morningcustomers are going to the counter to pay for food then they will have to cover up. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesButcustomers are sitting down to eat, they will be able to take their mask off once they have bought their food. Mr Hancock told Sky News this morning: You do need to wear a face mask in Pret because Pret is a shop - in hospitality, there needs to be table service.If theres table service, it is not necessary to have a mask. But in any shop, you do need the mask. So,youre going up to the counter in Pret to buy takeaway that is a shop, butyou go to your local pub you cant go to the bar.The reason is because of the risk of transmission over the bar. The new rules will make face masks compulsory from July  in England and people will face a £ finethey fail to comply.Face masks will not required in offices, Mr Hancock said, because it is generally the same group of people all sitting in one place - so social distancing is the best method to stop transmission. He said: “The reason for that is when you are in close proximity with somebody who you have to work closely with,you are there for a long time then a mask does not offer that protection, as opposed to a shop or public transport when you are with someone for a reasonable amount of time.“The point is when you are in interaction with people you aren’t normally with, that’s when the mask is particularly helpful.Yesterday, the Environment Secretary George Eustice refused to rule out masks in offices as the Governments top ministers struggled to understand their own policy.Mr Hancock was slammed by Lorraine Kelly this morning for the Governments relaxation of rules. title: priti patel coronavirus uk
story: The Home Secretary today revealed she did not know the number of infected coming into Britain, but insisted the figure was held “where” in the Government.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIn a heated Home Affairs Committee, chair and Labour MP Yvette Cooper asked for an “estimate” of the amount coming in.Ms Patel answered: “Well that I don’t know. “On a daily basis, the number of people coming into the country is approximately , people and that’s across all modes of transport.“I don’t have a figure of people coming into the country with coronavirus.“That figure is held centrally where across Government.”On May  Ms Patel announced the Government was enforcing a new quarantine measure to prevent a second wave of Covid-.The measures meant all visitors you had never asked for an estimate of how many people might be coming into the country with coronavirus.”Ms Patel denied the accusation, but again failed to give a number.She said: “The figure that I was given [in March was] . per cent of people will potentially bring in cases from outside of the UK into the UK.”Ms Cooper responded that the senior minister had given the same answer at the last evidence session, only to be corrected.She added: “Were you ever given, did you ever ask for, and were you ever given an estimate of the number of people coming into the country with coronavirus.”Ms title: meghan harry members club disneyland vegans campsite
story: Soho Farmhouse has won planning permission to build the ‘glamping’ site - nextdoor to the Beckham’s Cotswolds pile.⚠️Read our Meghan and Harry blog for the latest news on the Royal couple.The elite members’ club, where Meghan reportedly held her spa-themed hen do in , has been allowed to turn farmland into a trendy camping field called ‘Farm Camp’.It also asked West Oxfordshire District Councilit can move the five-a-side pitch as guests complained that it is affecting their sunbathing. The exclusive club, which has sites across Europe, North America and Asia, costs £, a year to join. And the Cotswolds reatreat is a popular hotspot for A-listers including Cara Delevingne, Eddie Redmayne and the Clooneys. Meghan, , joined former Made in Cha socialite Millie Mackintosh, , at Soho Farmhouse for a weekend break in . The Duchess of Sussex is also thought to have held her bridal bash there ahead of her wedding to Harry, , at Windsor Castle in May . The Oxfordshire lodge currently has a temporary campsite but has now got the go-ahead to allow guests to sleep under the stars in fancy bell tents on a permanent basis. Over the years, residents in the quaint village of Great Tew have become increasingly fed up with Soho Farmhouse’s expansion - especially about the increase in traffic and spike in road accidents. In the planning application for the luxury campsite, local Claire Berry expressed her outrage at all the ‘vegans’ visiting the club.She said they are ruining farmland by turning it into a ‘Disneyland’, which is inappropriate during the coronavirus pandemic. Claire wrote: “At a time when we need all our farmland, why is this land being changed  “I surmise that the customers of this campsite identy themselves as vegan vegetarian andwe are to feed the population that identies in this way we will need more farmland. “Therefore it would be something that these very customers will be against. “There is also the increase in traffic which is becoming a serious problem especially on Friday and Monday. “Looking at the figures in the PFA Consulting document of March , the numbers of cars on Friday th Oct  in Tracey Lane was , so will this change of use mean more customers and more cars ”Claire added: “Here we are in the middle of the Covid- pandemic which is nature biting back. It is a time when we should consider seriously how we go forward. “A campsite where customers are encouraged to drive  miles for a meal and an overnight is beginning to seem out of step with a world where the climate is falling apart due to pollution and now with a virus that is so dangerous. “Maybe now is the time for all of us to rethink and allowing much needed farmland to be converted to the equivalent of Disneyland is something that should be reconsidered.”The football pitch, which Soho Farmhouse wants to move, may appeal to former footie ace David Beckham, whose converted barn is just down the road. The application states it needs to be relocated due to complaints from guests, saying: “An operational review of feedback from members and hotel guests revealed that the five-a-side football pitch was the subject of numerous complaints from people relaxing by the swimming pool and sun lawns who felt the two activities were not compatible.“As a consequence of this review, a decision was made to explore other potential locations for the five-a-side football pitch. “The unused piece of land adjacent to Farm Camp lent itself perfectly to the proposed use, both in terms of its size and its location close to the changing and shower facilities in the gym.”The campsite will appeal to the rich and famous looking for a coronavirus-friendly getaway.Tents will be spaced so guests can socially distance and enjoy the fresh air - where experts say the virus is less likely to spread. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris announces coronavirus inquiry
story: The Prime Minister insisted now was not the time to start analysing how well the Government has responded to the pandemic but pledged to have one in the future. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMr Johnson told the House of Commons this lunchtime: I do not believe that now, in the middle of combatting a pandemic, as we still are, is the right moment to devote huge amounts of official time to an inquiry. Of course, we will seek to learn the lessons of this pandemic in the future and certainly we will have an independent inquiry into what happened. Officials said there was no date yet for an inquiry but it would come forward in due course.Its also not clear how much it might cost, who would lead the inquiry, and how long it would last.Many of the Governments top ministers have also stressed that it is too soon to start calling for an inquiry into coronavirus. There have been almost , deaths from coronavirus in the UK - the highest death toll in Europe. A report for Government scientists this week said a second wave in the winter could kill , people. One of the biggest issues MPs are keen to examine is how coronavirus wrought havoc in care homes. Questioning the PM today, Liberal Democrat MP Sir Ed Davey said: We have suffered one of the worst death rates in the world and Europes worst death rate for health and care workers. A report by the National Audit Office, assessing the readiness of the NHS and the social care sector for coronavirus, showed it was not known how many of the , people discharged from hospitals into care homes were infected with coronavirus. A fth of the nations most vulnerable people in care home have been infected by the deadly virus. There are also questions surrounding the Government decision to go into lockdown weeks later than many other European countries. The PM has backflipped on ious policies, including face masks - which will be mandatory from July  - but were previously not used because of claims they did not work. MPs have launched their own inquiry earlier this week with an All-Party Parliamentary Group, led by Liberal Democrat MP Layla Moran. Ms Moran said earlier this week: From the neglect of care homes to the lack of an effective testing regime, each day brings more evidence of mistakes in the handling of this pandemic – and there is every indication that we will see a potential second spike this winter.“The country and the NHS cannot afford for these errors to be repeated. title: doctor drink driving fit
story: A disciplinary  ruled that Dr Lauren Fowler, , posed no risk to patients despite crashing her Ford Ka twice whilst over the limit in .Dr Fowler had drunk white wine with friends over lunch in October , before crashing her car in a busy pedestrian area.She was so intoxicated that she was barely able to speak when police arrived at the scene and found an empty bottle of wine in the footwell of her car.She was bailed out - but was stopped again less than two months later, after she drunk half a bottle of vodka then drove around a hotel car park near her familys home in Styal, near Wilmslow, Cheshire.Tests showed she was over three times the drink-drive limit.Having graduated from Imperial College London with a degree in medicine just months earlier, Fowler claimed university stress drove her to rely on booze.In , she admitted drinking driving but was given a suspended jail sentence.The first year doctor later faced a misconduct hearing at the Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service in Manchester where she was told she could only continue working in medicine under supervision.Today, it emerged a fitness to practise  had lted the restrictions on Fowler and said she couldto work unsupervised following hearing largely held in private. The General Medical Council did not challenge the move.Since being arrested twice, she has given up drinking but is currently still serving a three-year driving ban.In a heavily redacted document issued after the hearing MPTS  chairman Miss Anya Lewis said: Since Dr Fowler’s conviction, there has been no repetition or suggestion of any repetition of such conduct.The tribunal is satisfied that Dr Fowler has developed further insight and sufficiently remediated so that there is no risk of repetition. There is no requirement to issue a further sanction.She added: Dr Fowler has remained in practice during very dficult and turbulent times both personally and professionally, during which she had maintained and improved her clinical skills.The Tribunal accepted that Dr Fowler recognises the gravity of her misconduct, has developed further insight, has taken the necessary steps to remedy her misconduct. The Tribunal is therefore satisfied that she is safe toto unrestricted practice, and that it is in the public interest for her to do so.Fowler had pursued her career in medicine after she excelled at Stockport Grammar School - where she was senior prefect and attained two A* grades and an A at A Level. She was also shortlisted for a UK Scientist of the Year award for a research project she carried out at Manchester University in .It is thought Fowler attended Clare College at Cambridge before enrolling in  at Imperial College.But within days of her graduation ceremony in October , Fowler went out for lunch in Manchester during which she shared a bottle of wine with friends - and then drank more wine whilst at the wheel of her car before crashing it.Police attended the scene and found a clearly intoxicated Fowler swearing and slurring her words and they could smell intoxicants on her breath. As she was arrested, she admitted that she had drunk two bottles of wine and was taken to the police station. She was described as acting very emotionally and she failed to provide a specimen of breath because she was so upset.Fowler was bailed to face court but was held again on December   after being caught drinking driving at the Stanneylands boutique hotel in Wilmslow. Police said she had collided with another car whilst trying to leave the car park of the Stanneylands Hotel. When officers arrived they tried to speak to her, but the noticed a smell of intoxicants on her breath and she was slurring her words.In an interview, she said she had drunk half a bottle of vodka before deciding to go to the gym.Tests showed Fowler had  mg of alcohol in  millilitres of breath. The legal limit is mg.Fowler had to abide by the restrictions on her job for  months but were lted with immediate effect.Her lawyer Miles Bennett said: Nothing will minimise the seriousness of Dr Fowler’s conduct but that the concerns of the  Tribunal has been fully addressed by Dr Fowler. She has risen to the challenge and had exceeded it and evidence presented today by the GMC was positive and that none of it was conflicting in nature. Her fitness to practise medicine is no longer impaired by her convictions.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Captain Tom has said that meeting the Queen at Windsor Castle will be the most special of days for the WWII veteran.The WWII veteran raised more than £million for NHS charities by walking  laps of his garden before his th birthday in April.Captain Tom will pick up the gong from the Queen, , on Friday at the special ceremony.The -year-old tweeted his excitement: I could never have imagined this would happen to me.It is such a huge honour and I am very much looking forward to meeting Her Majesty The Queen.It is going to be the most special of days for me.There were initial fears the ceremony may have been delayed until the end of the year due to lockdown rules.It will be the first investiture since lockdown four months ago when the Queen left Buckingham Palace.Captain Tom will be accompanied by members of his family and the ceremony will take place inside the castle grounds.During the open-air ceremony, The Queen will use the sword that belonged to her father, George VI and will award Captain Sir Thomas Moore with the insignia of Knight Bachelor.Members of the public are asked not to attend Windsor town centre or gather in the hope of seeing any of the ceremony.It will be the first time the Queen emerges from lockdown a scaled-back social-distancing Trooping the Colour inside Windsor Castle on June .Captain Tom served in WWII, but at aged  he embarked on  laps of his garden in a bid to raise £, for NHS Charities Together.On the morning of his th birthday he surpassed £million and the campaign closed at £.m.He featured on a cover version of the song Youll Never Walk Alone with proceeds going to same charity.At the beginning of the pandemic and before lockdown the Queen wore gloves to hand out gongs.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Karl Molyneaux tried to kill the mum-of-two with nine kne blows, before leaving her bleeding heavily on the floor at the home in South Shields.She had told him she wanted to spend a night alone with her children - causing him to snap and attack her with a kne.The -year-old then fled to a nearby petrol station where he called  and told them: I have just stabbed my girlfriend.She will need an ambulance.When askedshe was bleeding heavily he replied: I dont know. I just ran.He added: We just had an argument so I just snapped.When asked whereabouts he stabbed her he said: Near the neck.Newcastle Crown Court heard the former serviceman had felt rejected when he was told not to come round - but he turned up anyway, with flowers and a takeaway.He told detectives after the stabbing he had snapped and that his feelings had been hurt and he wanted to hurt her in .The woman, a care home manager, was taken to hospital for emergency surgery after suffering multiple stab wounds to her face, neck and arm.She was found by her son and daughter, who were upstairs at the time.At Newcastle Crown Court Molyneaux, of Eglesfield Road, South Shields, who worked for South Tynside Council as a care quality commissioner, pleaded guilty to attempted murder.Judge Paul Sloan QC sentenced him to -and-a-half years behind bars with a lelong restraining order to keep him away from the victim.The judge said Molyneauxs feeling of rejection triggered a horric and angry response.Judge Sloan told him: You launched a savage and sustained attack on her with a kne, stabbing and slashing her repeatedly to the face, neck and torso as well as her right arm.The injuries represent nine separate actions with the kne.The wounds to the neck came perilously close to the carotid artery and the jugular vein. Had they been severed, the incident could well have proved fatal.It was simply a matter of chance that those vessels were not damaged.You told interviewing officers your feelings had been hurt and so you wanted to hurt her.When she told you to lock the door on your way out you feared it may be the end of the relationship.The court heard the couple had had a decade long friendship before their relationship formed and Molyneaux had proposed marriage, even though his orce wasnt final but the victim had told she was not ready for such commitment.Molyneaux was jealous of the friendship his victim still had with her former partner.Prosecutor Nick Dry said the jealously manested itself with controlling, possessive and obsessive behaviour which led to arguments, following which Molyneaux would turn up with gts like soft toys and flowers.The couple were arguing in the kitchen on the night of the attack.Mr Dry added: At that point, the defendant approached her in a manner which appeared asto embrace her.Instead, unbeknown to her, as he advanced upon her the defendant picked up a kitchen kne.He then took hold of her around the neck and she felt his fingers in her mouth then a sharp pain to her face and neck as she was repeatedly stabbed before the defendant fled the house.The court heard the victims children rushed to her aid and she was taken to hospital.She suffered a wound that went through her cheek into her mouth, a gaping wound to her neck and other stab and slash marks that will leave lelong scars.The victim still struggles to use one arm due to muscle damage and has had to leave her home due to the psychological trauma caused to her and her children.She said in a statement: I am extremely upset and in disbelief that Karl has done this to me – I cannot believe he is capable of this.I am worried about my children as they were in my house at the time and I had to ask them for help. I tried to help myself but I was in so much pain.This has turned my world upside down. I need to know why this has happened.Robin Patton, defending, said Molyneaux has been assessed by two psychiatrists who agree he does not pose a risk of harm to other people and is keen to show genuine remorse and shame for what he has done.Mr Patton said Molyneaux, who was in the army, had a history of mental health problems, including potential PTSD and had been off work due to depression and anxiety before the attack.Detective Sergeant Gaye Martin, of Northumbria Police, said: This was an appalling and cowardly attack as Molyneaux – somebody with no previous offending history – attempted to kill somebody who he should have been caring for.His actions were cold and sinister, leaving his girlfriend to fight for her le with catastrophic injuries.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA swathe of new jobcentres looks set to open within months - just two years after the Tories shut  in a cost-cutting drive. Officials face a backlash after announcing a “rapid” bid for new buildings to deal with coronavirus. Ministers could even reopen some of the same job centres they shut - despite protests at the time - after more than million people claimed Universal Credit since March. It came as a minister claimed he had seen no evidence the five-week wait for UC plunges people into debt - despite warnings from a string of charities and the National Audit Office. Will Quince instead blamed “scaremongering” about the benefit for making people late to claim - leading one MP to brand him beyond pompous. More than  Jobcentres were shuttered between  and , many of them merged with nearby centres or “co-located” with councils. The Toriesapos  spending review said cutting the number of jobcentres would reduce estate costs by %. But the Department for Work of Pensionsis now doubling its work coaches from , to , to deal with the pandemic in an £m boost. While , due by October can fit into existing centres, the other , - due by March  - will need “new estate”, chief Neil Couling confirmed. Askedthe new work coaches would work in an office, or from home, the Universal Credit Director-General put the emphasis on offices.  He told MPs on the Work and Pensions Committee: “The first , [work coaches] we can fit into our existing estate and properties. We’ve been carefully checking that’s all Covid-compliant, working with our local trade unions on all of that. But after that, we’re going to need new estate. So we’re currently in discussions about acquiring that to a rapid timetable. He said reopening shuttered job centres was “a possibility” and at least one is being examined now, “but in general I think these will be newer properties.” Mr Couling made the admission to SNP MP Chris Stephens - who fought the closure of half of Glasgow’s Jobcentres two years ago. He said: “This decision was always going to impact on services especially during an economic downturn, when unemployment rises. Today’s extraordinary admission demonstrates that the decision to close job centres was wrong then and wrong now.PCS union general secretary Mark Serwotka said: “This is a startling admission that clearly shows closing job centres in  was a mistake. “Calamitous ministers are on one hand saying we rightly need more staff but don’t have the space to accommodate them in the current jobcentre estate.” He called for an end to benefit sanctions saying “there clearly will be a major jobs shortage.” It came as MPs and a minister rowed over the five-week wait for the first payment of Universal Credit. Campaigners say despite people being able to get an advance payment, many are turning to food banks and struggling to get by. The National Audit Office last week said the standard wait for first payment “can exacerbate claimants’ debt and financial dficulties”, with many organisations saying it causes “hardship”.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA greyhound has found her forever home in the UK after being rescued from a le of cruelty at a notorious Chinese racetrack. Libby now lives with her new owner in Somerset after escaping from the infamous Macau Canidrome where dogs were killed every day while being kept in appalling conditions. The now happy and well-fed dog was one of the many thousands of greyhounds forced to run at Asiaaposs last remaining racetrack that became infamous for its dire mistreatment of animals. The unfortunate greyhounds and lurchers that ended up there endured a le of abuse, neglect, exploitation and injury before being put down, often at a young age. Libby is one of the few dogs to have left the stadium - where gamblers staked their money on the misery of animals - alive. During the time it was in operation, it is estimated that , dogs died at the canidrome and records show that an animal was put down every day. Like the other dogs living there, Libby slept on the hard floor of its cramped kennel with no bedding and rarely -ever - ventured outside of its concrete confines. Libby never experienced walks or grass under her feet and was given minimal medical care by her callous owners. Without a pet adoption programme, many of the dogs there would simply be euthanisedthey ever became sick or unable to race.  Records show Libby ended up in the canidrome as a puppy after being sold by cruel dog breeders in Australia, following the fate of many before her. Betting is big business in Macau, a Special Administrative Region within China, known for its giant casinos and reputation as the worldaposs biggest gambling hub. First opened in , the cityaposs canidrome was supplied with hundreds of greyhounds every year, many of which would come from Australia and beyond.  As its profile grew, demands for its closure by animal rights activists grew louder as they pressured Australiaaposs government and racing bodies to block the exports of greyhounds to the territory. As the supply eventually dwindled unscrupulous owners in Ireland and in the UK stepped in to fill the void, readily selling young greyhounds to agents in Hong Kong. After years of dwindling interest from locals and pressure from authorities the stadium shut its doors for good in . But the closure left  canines without a home and an international effort was launched to house them.Libby was one of five dogs that the Forever Hounds Trust rescued from the Macau racetrack where  dogs have now been successfully adopted.Their condition was described as being in a very poor state and it took at least three months for them to learn to become pets and not just a racing commodity. Her new owner Saz, says that when Libby first arrived in her new home in Wellington, near Taunton, she was slow to adapt to her new le of comforts.Libby didn’t know how to go up and down stairs or get on the sofa at first, but soon learned how comfortable it was to sleep on her own bed in a video that since went viral on Facebook. She said: “It breaks my heart to think of Libby in the Canidrome, and what could have happened to heranimal welfare group ANIMA and Forever Hounds Trust hadn’t been there to help her. “But when you see her now you cannot believe she has spent all her le in the Canidrome. She loves to play and chases tennis balls and she has learnt how much fun it can be to go out for a walk.

When she was , the conniving predator then had sex with a -year-old girl, having also misled this child about her gender. Davidson was released from prison on May  last year and moved to Liverpool, where she was befriended by an adult woman. But the woman - who didnapost know about Davidsonaposs sinister past - introduced the pervert, then , to her -year-old daughter. Liverpool Crown Court heard Davidson is subject to an indefinite Sexual Harm Prevention Order , which bans her from any contact with children under the age of , except for contact that is inadvertent or with the informed consent of the childaposs parent or . Michael Stephenson, prosecuting, said the mum - an ex-con - took the defendant under her wing after a fashion because she was being bullied. He said: She said she had no awareness of the nature of the defendantaposs convictions. She thought that she had been sentenced for either drugs or some sort of violence and thought she was a fairly harmless kid, because of her youthful appearance. The mum said Davidson met with her daughter about  times between May  and June , but suspected they also met in private. Davidson later confessed to police that she and the child twice met alone, but insisted there was no physical activity between them. On June , the woman was walking down the street, ahead of Davidson and her daughter, when she heard them arguing. Mr Stephenson said: She heard her daughter saying to the defendant aposI could get you killedapos and she then told her mother aposthis soft c*** said she is in love with meapos. The defendant was crying and said she was sorry. The police were contacted and Davidson was recalled on licence to prison. Officers examined her mobile phone and found she and the girl exchanged  text messages and  phone calls in little over a week. Mr Stephenson said the girl refused to give an interview to police and expressed the view Davidson had done nothing wrong at one stage. When interviewed in November, Davidson admitted having a romantic attachment to the child, and said she considered her a girlfriend. She claimed the girlaposs mum was aware of their developing relationship, but the woman denied this. Davidson, now , of no fixed address but formerly of Rhyl, North Wales, admitted breaching her SHPO. Her previous convictions are for five counts of sexual activity with a child in February . Thomas Sherrington, defending, conceded there had been a risk of his client forming a physical relationship with the girl. He said: What this appears to be is a rather warped sense of the reality of the seriousness of the situation the defendant found herself in, an inappropriate in fact relationship, with a child. The lawyer said Davidson was remorseful and wanted to express her sorrow and guilt. He said: She says how foolish she acted considering she had been released from prison some  days prior and was well aware of the terms of the order, but her feelings got the better of her. She has said to me today she feels like she will be able to get the help and assistance she needs in order to combat this behaviour now she has ed to custody. Mr Sherrington added: She tells me she has been diagnosed with borderline personality disorder and emotional distress disorder. She is currently on medication in prison for these mental health disorders and suspects there may be some correlation between that and her offending.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The friend of a man who live-streamed his own death on Facebook smashed in a door and desperately tried to save him - but was too late.Jonathan Bailey, who was known as Baz or Bazza, told his Facebook followers that he was going to kill himself before he began the stream from his flat last Saturday, just days after his th birthday. His distressed friends desperately alerted Facebook to what was happening, but the live-stream continued as personal trainer Mr Bailey died by suicide in Newcastle-under-Lyme, Staffordshire.Mental health campaigner Craig Spillane, who found Mr Baileyaposs body after breaking down the door of his flat, told StokeonTrentLive he called  five times over the course of a week in a bid to get his friend help.Have you been affected by this story  Email webnews@mirror.  He said it was the third time dad-of-four Mr Bailey, a former boxer and community worker, had made an attempt on his own le in the space of a few days. Mr Spillane, a -year-old electrician who now helps others after struggling with suicidal thoughts, decided to speak out to raise awareness of how mental health services allegedly let Mr Bailey down. Friends pleaded with Mr Bailey to not give up and stay strong after he said he would take his own le. One wrote we are all here for you. It is thought up to  people were watching some of his last moments.  Mr Spillane, who runs the Men Unite group, said: I was at home when my girlfriendaposs daughter shouted to me to say that Baz was on Facebook threatening to kill himself. I called  and got in my car straight away. When I arrived I saw the police van had parked up. I shouted to the officers to askthey were looking for Bazaposs flat as they were in the wrong place. I then sprinted up the stairs. I tried his door but the chain was still on. I smashed my way in and thataposs when I saw him. I was screaming for help. We started CPR and at one point we had a faint pulse but it was too late. I just held him in my arms. There were eight police officers in the flat and then the paramedics arrived. Mr Bailey was pronounced dead at the scene. Mr Spillane added: Baz called me on the Monday on his th birthday and thanked me for setting up Men Unite and told me then that he was done.  As soon as I was off the phone I called  and got the police and ambulance out because he had taken an overdose. He was out in his van at the time. Then on the Wednesday he made another attempt on his le. Then on the Friday our friend Stefan Hanks rang to say he had Baz in the car. I rang  saying he needed to be sectioned. They just fobbed me off.  I told Stefan to take him to Harplands car park. He was then taken to AE but he left. It was actually the security guard who rang Stefan. Stefan and another friend then found Baz wandering around the car park. They got him in the car and bought him a KFC and as far as we were aware we thought heaposd be OK. They got him home and left him to sleep. The next day I tried to call Baz but I didnapost get any response and a short time later the live stream started. He had battled his demons for a long time. He just couldnapost beat them on his own. A week before he died, Mr Bailey put up a Facebook post with a broken heart emoji, writing: Moral of the story. Donapost give your heart to anyone. They will break it it. Hours earlier, he wrote: Liars and cheats always try and turn things round and worm their way out of it. Definitely staying on my own from now on.  The next day, his birthday, he wrote: Iaposm done. It came just days after he mourned the loss of a friend, writing still canapost believe youaposre gone brother. Mr Spillane described his close friend as one-of-a-kind. Mr Bailey had founded the Ultimate Fitness Centre in Chesterton and in recent years campaigned to rid the streets of the psychoactive drug monkey dust, which his son had struggled with.  Mr Spillane said: He would go out of his way and bend over backwards to help others. We knew how much he was struggling. Itaposs such a tragic loss of a brilliant man. North Staffordshire Combined Healthcare NHS Trust - which runs Harplands - said it has launched an investigation. A spokesman said: As one of a number of providers of mental health and substance misuse services and support across Stoke-on-Trent and Staffordshire, we are acutely aware of the risks and issues facing us all at this unique time.  In line with our normal legal responsibilities, we are sure people will understand that we cannot comment on inidual cases or specic events until a full investigation has taken place and the full facts established. We can confirm that all the necessary processes are now underway and our thoughts and condolences are with the family. We are working with our local health and care partners and the local voluntary sector to continually improve our service offer, including ensuring that people are fully aware of, and can easily access, the range of services available across the county. We all have an ethical and moral responsibility to do everything we can to approach this dficult issue responsibly and without causing unnecessary further distress or potential harm to our local communities and vulnerable people.” Facebook has said it had provided fitness fan Baz with support resources following his initial post on Saturday afternoon. The live-stream was later deleted. A Facebook spokesman said: “Our thoughts go out to Mr Bailey’s family at this dficult time. We can confirm that the live-stream was deleted very soon after being posted and a further post has also now been removed at the family’s request.

The popular online brand has confirmed  workers at the site have tested positive for the virus.The warehouse previously described as a breeding ground for Covid-  has been investigated after employees caught the illness, reports Examiner Live. Clipper logistics operates the depot at the site in South Yorkshire. It comes after a wave of outbreaks were linked to meat processing plants, and concerns have been raised over conditions at the UKaposs garment factories too. Pretty Little Thing is owned by fashion retailer Boohoo,which is facing scandals over the brandaposs warehouse workersapos pay and conditions in Leicester, the first UK area to go into a local lockdown. Click here for the latest coronavirus news and updates Sheffield MP Clive Betts said a public health investigation into the Pretty Little Thing warehouse began about a month ago after it was found the virus had been transmitted into the community rather than in the workplace. He added it emerged most of those who contracted the illness lived together and shared lts to work. The MP claimed he had been contacted by around  workers during the pandemic who are concerned about coronavirus precautions in place at the warehouse.It had also been reported that workers were finding it impossible to maintain safe social distancing principles as they worked alongside their colleagues. One worker told the BBC that the aisles in the warehouse are ft foot wide, with up to  people working in them at any one time.  Workers have also complained of a shortage of hand sanitiser.One of them told the  BBC : Going to work has the chance of killing me and infecting my grandson. To save lives, shut the place.A spokesman for Pretty Little Thing said: Since the onset of the pandemic Clipper logistics, who operate the warehouse in Sheffield have been closely following and adhering to all the guidance provided by the Government. To operate safely, they have fundamentally changed how they operate the warehouse to accommodate all the necessary social distancing, hygiene and self-isolation rules to eliminate risk and to keep everyone safe. They have ensured that they have kept local officials and the Environmental Health updated and offered an open invitation for them to visit  whenever they wanted to inspect, to speak to employees and to offer any advice on any additional measures that they could be taking, because the absolute priority is to protect the wellbeing of everyone in the Clipper team.  The EHOhave visited the site on numerous occasions and we would point you to the statement that their Director of Public Health issues on  July which clearly states that transmission is likely to have occurred in households not the workplace. Sheffield City Council director of public health Greg Fell said: We are aware of the business in question and they have cooperated fully by implementing appropriate health and safety measures with support and guidance from our Environmental Health teams.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailHero fundraiser Captain Tom Moore will be knighted by the Queen in his own personal ceremony at Windsor Castle on Friday. It is the first time that the monarch - who has been isolating since the start of the lockdown - has made a public engagement since March . She was seen in public for the first time since lockdown on June  when she attended a stripped back Trooping the Colour. Captain Tom, who turned  in April, raised nearly £million for health service charities by walking laps of his Bedfordshire garden. He will travel with members of his family for the rare, special investiture with the monarch. Royal investitures were put on hold during the pandemic, and those scheduled to take place at Buckingham Palace and the Palace of Holyroodhouse in Edinburgh in June and July were postponed. But the -year-old Queen, who has been staying at Windsor since before lockdown for her safety, will carry out the official engagement in person - rare for the monarch during the pandemic - to honour Captain Tom. It is her first public appearance since Commonwealth Day, when she stood alongside Prince Harry and Meghan Markle in one of the coupleaposs last frontline royal engagements. The monarch will use the sword that belonged to her father, George VI, and will present him with the insignia of Knight Bachelor.  The ceremony will take place entirely within the confines of Windsor Castle, with no viewing positions for the public. Members of the public are being asked not to attend Windsor town centre or gather in the hope of seeing any of the ceremony, which will not be visible from any external viewpoint. Captain Tom had set out to raise £,, but his incredible gesture won him fans around the world and saw his fundraising efforts soar. In honour of his incredible achievement, he was given a flypast on his th birthday.  Captain Tom also became the oldest person to ever score a UK Number One single with his rendition of Youaposll Never Walk Alone, recorded with Michael Ball and the NHS Voices Of Care Choir. And his incredible efforts saw him awarded a special Pride Of Britain award. Captain Tom said the response to his charitable efforts had been outstanding. He said: Itaposs hard to describe thereaposs been so much kindness shown and so many people making kind remarks.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA rise in new coronavirus cases among people living in terraced houses has sparked fears of a fresh lockdown in Blackburn. Today a health boss warned that a rising tide has been found in areas with a high number of terraced houses where multiple people live. The outbreak in Blackburn with Darwen is centred on the areaaposs Asian community, Professor Dominic Harrison, the local authorityaposs director of public health, said. He warned that the area could follow Leicester back into lockdown in just two weeksthis trend is not reversed.It is one of  areas named as being at risk of a fresh outbreak.The Lancashire town brought in extra restrictions yesterday, banning large groups from visiting each other and instructing people not to shake hands. Prof Harrison, speaking on BBC Radio aposs Today programme, said: We have what we call a rising tide event rather than an outbreak, and by that we mean that weaposve got a number of cases rising in specic areas across a signicant community, but not a single big outbreak like Kirklees or other areas that had a workplace outbreak.  It can have the same effect because it can drive up the cases, but what we are seeing from looking at the postcode data of those cases is, in the last couple of weeks, is that what we are seeing is a single case being infected, then going back to a household and all that household becoming infected. And when we look at the data what we can see is clusters in a part of the town, but the clusters are household clusters, so a number of those are causing the rising tide event and we know that they are in mainly south-Asian areas, and they are in areas with high number of terraced houses with high numbers of occupants in the house, so four or more, five or more people in the household. He said the Blackburn with Darwen borough, which has an Asian population of about %, had  cases in the last two weeks and  of those cases are south Asian.  The rate of confirmed cases per , has gone up to  per ,, up from . cases in the seven days to July . The authority is third on the list of highest weekly rates, behind Leicester, which has a rate of . cases per , and is subject to a local lockdown, and nearby Pendle, with a rate of .. Prof Harrison said this has triggered the local response, with the establishment of an outbreak control management board and five extra measures introduced. These are: A limit of two people from the same household allowed to visit another household.  At the moment national guidance allows two families to meet indoors as long as they keep to social distancing guidance. The council are asking residents to limit the numbers of people meeting indoors to people who live in the house plus only two members from a second household at any one time. Wearing cloth face coverings in all enclosed public spaces.  All residents will be strongly recommended to wear a cloth face coveringin all enclosed public spaces. This means in all shops, workplaces, libraries, museums, health centres, hair and beauty salons etc. Greeting and embracing.  Rather than give handshakes or a hug, the council are asking people to only bump elbows with anyone outside of their immediate family. Support for small shops.  The council are stepping up our Public Protection advice and support to small shops across the borough to ensure that measures such as wearing face coverings, social distancing, good hygiene practice and increased ventilation are being followed to help reduce the risk of virus spread in these businesses. Testing.  The council are doing more targeted testing this week, with the arrival of a mobile testing unit at Witton Park Academy in addition to the testing facility at Royal Blackburn Hospital. You don’t need to have symptoms to be tested – this will help us with case finding, identying people who have no symptoms but who carry the virus. Prof Harrison added: If numbers are not turning round and going down again by July , so two weeks, we are going to then have our next stage, we will go through the lockdown lting measures and reverse them one by one until the numbers go down.

title: bid to extort 10k from secret escort
story: A man threatened to expose a woman’s secret le as an escort unless she gave him £, to keep quiet.John Menzie, of Gleneagles Road, ordered the woman to pay him the hush money infor her activities remaining a secret from her loved ones and her employer.In a menacing letter, the -year-old wrote: “Do you remember the old saying your past is creeping up on you  Well yours is about to rear its ugly head.”Dundee Sherf Court heard Menzie was hoping to use some of the money to take his partner on holiday after she had completed treatment for breast cancer.Menzie lied to the woman – who can only be referred to as “JE” for legal reasons – about having video footage of her with a client.Fiscal depute Eilidh Robertson said: “No one in the complainer’s le is aware she has undertaken this work. The accused had found out as a result of a friend spotting her on an adult website.”Menzie wrote in the letter: “Can you imagine what this will do to you and your family  When this gets in the hands of the newspaper “They will have a field day. Warning – you will not discuss this with anyone. I have made an arrangement to have the information passed on. I will tell you where you make the drop-off.”Ms Robertson added: “The complainer felt immediately threatened and worried.”The woman contacted the police and a search warrant was obtained for Menzie’s home.He was arrested and almost immediately admitted the offence, claiming he had done it because he was in “big debt” and had mental health issues.During a police interview, Menzie said he had wanted to take his partner away once she had an operation for breast cancer. title: dundee united micky mellon mark ogren
story: Dundee United boss Micky Mellon has revealed he has the backing of owner Mark Ogren in the transfer market.Mellon, who signed a two-year deal to be United’s new manager last week, was assured by the club’s American owner he’ll be able to strengthen his squad in the summer window.However, the -year-old gaffer plans to take his time to assess the current crop first before working with sporting director Tony Asghar to improve the Tangerines’ pool.“It’s a bit early and a bit unfair on the champions of the Championship,” the former Tranmere Rovers man said.“They deserve great respect. It’s been a great shame they haven’t been able to celebrate that.“The club will find some way of they get their day with that.“In terms of recruitment and brining players in, I’ll give the players here the opportunity.“I’ll take my time with that. Assurances is a strong word but certainly Dundee United as a club would have the ability to go out and do that,I can bring players that would make Dundee United a better team.“They’d have the ability to go into the market and bring players in that could make the team better.“If the need is there for me to go and do that, and the opportunity to bring players in from other places I believe is a good fit for the culture of the club and making the team better, then absolutely we would have the ability to do that.“The owner has told me he’d back me as has Tony Asghar and I’m happy with that.”As for how United’s embroilment in Hearts and Partick Thistle’s legal case against the SPFL affects his ability to spend, Mellon says that is for those higher up at Tannadice to say.An SFA arbitration  will hear the Jags and Jambos’ petition this week with league champions United, Raith Rovers and Cove Rangers mounting their own defences in the wake of the initial SPFL resolution and Court of Session action.“I think that’s a question for other people,” he said of the impact United’s legal costs on his playing budget.“I’ve, obviously, been brought here to try to improve a football team.“I’m here try to build relationships with fans and connect everybody, to make players understand the sacrices you need to make to improve and the other stuff will be taken care of by specialists.“They’ll get on with that, that’s what they’re here to do and paid to do, that’s not my remit.“I’ll do what I’m here to do which is digest training, see what I think our players need to do I order to keep moving them forward and then get out on the grass to put on sessions that will challenge them.“Once I see the improvements that need to be made, I’ll be strong with them and keep the standards really high.“I need to keep them fit and motivated and away we go. I’ll do that every day.“That’s just the way I work and operate as a manager. It’s stood me in good stead and I won’t change that.”Mellon’s track record in developing players is impressive with Leicester star Jamie Vardy one of his students at Fleetwood Town and Manchester City ace John Stones another at Barnsley.However, the Paisley-born coach was keen to point out another in Rangers defender Connor Goldson, whom Mellon had at Shrewsbury.He hopes to repeat those kind of successes at United.He added: “I had Connor Goldson. We developed him into a fantastic centre-back and sold him to Brighton for millions.“You take your time with them and see what they need to get better at. It was the same with Vardy, Stones and these kind of guys.“You look at it and know the qualities that’s needed for them to be a top player.“You recognise it and because I’ve been through it before and been successful with it before because the proof is there with the boys playing at unbelievable levels, I’m able to bring that to this group of players.“I know the techniques that are needed to show them. The training sessions or talking to them about things in a way they can grasp and understand to make them top players as well.“I really enjoy doing that and I’m so proud of all the boys who have turned out top players.”CALUM WOODGER: New Dundee United boss Micky Mellon is making all the right noises" title"#CALUM WOODGER: New Dundee United boss Micky Mellon is making all the right noises# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp calum-woodger-new-dundee-united-micky-mellon-making-right-noises embed # secretZZoTJol" data-secret"ZZoTJol" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: dundee united nicky clark micky mellon
story: Nicky Clark believes the whole Dundee United squad are enjoying a clean slate under new boss Micky Mellon.Mellon last week signed a two-year agreement to become United manager, replacing Robbie Neilson after his departure for Hearts.Attacker Clark feels the -year-old’s arrival at Tannadice has given everyone a lt.“It has brought a freshness and a clean slate for everyone,” the -year-old said.“He has told us he is looking at us all and he will make judgement with his own eyes and not from what he hears from other people.“He has made it clear it will be his view and he will tell us where we are strong and in what areas we can improve both collectively and inidually.”Clark insists Mellon already has the respect of the players courtesy of a stellar management career in the lower leagues down south with Fleetwood Town, Shrewsbury and Tranmere.Not much has changed on the training pitch since Neilson’s exit but Clark says the players are already seeing a manager they’re looking forward to working for.He continued: “When a new manager comes in he has his own way of playing and doing things.“It is down to the boys to adapt to that because it will be dferent from what we were used to under the previous management team.“The gaffer hasn’t done too much dferently. He has watched closely and put his own inputs where he has felt he has had to, which has been good.“He has been down south all his managerial career and he comes here with new ideas and he is another top manager that we can learn from.“It is an exciting time for the whole club going into the Premiership and with the new manager coming in.“He comes across as a real players’ manager.“He told us that right at the start, for us to do well he needs us to do well.“He has told us his door is always open and he is always there to help.“We know that he is demanding and he will want to maintain the standards he has set in his time in England.“His record in England is great. He has five promotions and you can’t argue with that. It is definitely exciting times.”Former Rangers and Dunfermline man Clark was a key component of the Tangerines’ Championship title winning squad from last term.He is now hoping Mellon gives him and the other medal winners a chance to prove they can do it in the Premiership.Clark added: “The boys were excellent last season and we deservedly won the league although it wasn’t the way we wanted it to be.“At the end of the day we are champions and it is good to hear the manager will give us a chance.“However, we all know that he will bring in some new faces and over the next few days and weeks because he will want to strengthenthere are areas where he feels he needs to strengthen.“We will have to work hard and keep strivingwe want to keep raising the standards to meet the challenge of the Premiership week in, week out.”Clark ed from six months out with an ankle injury in a - friendly defeat at Motherwell on Saturday.It wasn’t the result the Terrors were after but the former Queen of the South man was just delighted to get back on the pitch.He commented: “It was a good run out. It has been a long time coming for me because it was my first game since January but it was good to get out there and going again.“It was exciting to be back playing again. I could have been backthe season hadn’t been cut short but this extra time has given me more opportunity to get everything % right and a good pre-season behind me.“It was a mix of experienced boys and younger lads but it was a good game.“We got beat - but at this stage it is all about fitness and boys coming through injury free.“The boys have all come back flying. They all tuned into it during the lockdown and we are reaping the benefits of that fitness now.”Dundee United boss Micky Mellon reveals he has backing of owner Mark Ogren in transfer market" title"#Dundee United boss Micky Mellon reveals he has backing of owner Mark Ogren in transfer market# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united-micky-mellon-mark-ogren embed # secretrQTIok" data-secret"rQTIok" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: coronavirus uk government supports wages of more than 80000 jobs across north east during lockdown
story: The UK Government has paid the wages of more than , north-east workers under schemes set up to provide financial support during lockown.New figures released today show that , people from across the region were supported under the job retention and self-employment income support schemes.The two initiatives are run by HM Revenue and Customsas part of a package of support measures for businesses affected by the coronavirus outbreak.Businesses have furloughed , jobs in Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire and Moray, up to May  , since the job retention scheme was launched on April .The move will help UK employers who have been severely affected by coronavirus to retain their employees.An announcement was made on May  that the scheme will run until the end of October to continue the support for jobs and businesses as peopleto work.The self-employment income support scheme was rolled out ahead of schedule in May and has financially supported , self-employed iniduals in the north-east who have been adversely affected by the coronavirus outbreak and paid grants worth a total of £. million up to May  .On  May , the Chancellor announced an extension to the programme. Those eligible to claim the SEISS grant will be able to claim a second and final grant in August of up to £,.Rishi Sunak, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said: #The UK Government is doing everything we can to protect jobs and businesses in Scotland and across the UK during the crisis.#Our unprecedented job retention and self-employment support schemes have supported the livelihoods of millions and will help ensure our recovery is as swt as possible.#Scottish minister David Duguid said: #The UK Government#s direct coronavirus support to people and businesses in the north-east has meant that , workers have been furloughed, and £. million has been spent on supporting , local self-employed people.#The north-east has also benefited from the UK-wide schemes which support iniduals and businesses, including Universal Credit.#This direct cash comes on top of an additional £. billion in extra funding for the Scottish Government through the Barnett Formula.#The UK Government is doing whatever it takes to get all parts of Scotland through the coronavirus pandemic and ensure our economy can get back on track as we recover.#For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancellation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Evening Express website including all Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening Express n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb and ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayUnlimited access to all articles on the Evening Express website. title: plans for aberdeen swimming pool given the go ahead
story: Ambitious proposals to extend an Aberdeen swimming pool have been approved.Northfield Pool is to be refurbished, and will include a -station gym, a multi-purpose studio, group and family changing facilities.There will also be new flooring and re-tiling, the replacement of fixtures and fittings, new suspended ceilings as well as additional car and cycle parking.It is expected to reopen in autumn .A planning application was submitted to Aberdeen City Council in March. title: queen victoria arrives in style
story: Queen Victoria and her husband Prince Albert visited Aberdeen for the first time on September  .The first monarchs to visit Aberdeen in over  years, they travelled from London by sea aboard the Royal Yacht. The town council commissioned a triumphal arch to mark the starting point for the royal procession.The triumphal arch was built for the north end of Waterloo Quay, under the supervision of Aberdonian architect John Smith. The wooden structure was made of three arched passageways, measuring up to  ftfrom the ground to the top parapet, and decorated to look like granite.This brightly painted crown represents Queen Victoria’s imperial crown. Now at Aberdeen Maritime Museum, it would have sat above the royal arms at the very top of the arch.It has been decorated with alternate crosses and fleurs-de-lis. The bottom has been painted to look like a crown trimmed in ermine whilst the main band and arches are painted gold and decorated with bright jewels and pearls. When the Royal Yacht entered the harbour, it was able to moor directly alongside the quay. It demonstrates the forethought and ingenuity of Aberdeen and its harbour: at no other dock in the British empire was this possible at this time.Queen Victoria and her family arrived  hours early, catching the expectant Aberdonians off-guard. Victoria remained onboard the Royal Yacht so as to not disappoint the crowds. The royal family entered through the arch and were welcomed by dignitaries, before proceeding on a royal procession to Balmoral.Queen Victoria and Albert quickly came to love and appreciate the tranquillity of a Highland le. title: cosgrove looking set to command better fee at transfer time
story: Aberdeen can anticipate further bids for Sam Cosgrove during the summer transfer window now word is out on how much they will accept for their leading scorer.Aberdeen agreed to a £ million bid from French second-tier side Guingamp for the striker who smashed in  goals last season.Clubs south of the border such as Championship outfits Stoke City and Middlesbrough have had Cosgrove watched.The Dons have projected £m losses due to the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.Chairman Dave Cormack recently insisted the Dons would not sell any of their star assets below market value despite the crisis.However, a -goal-a-season striker for around £m plus will be seen as a great deal by many English clubs.Cosgrove netted  times in the - They may think they are fine and the risk is minimal, but what about the thousand other folk with the same attitude near the same beauty spot This self-centred approach is also witnessed in the nature and volume of litter discarded. What goes through peoples# minds to leave their filth behind them The majority of bikers are fine # eventheir machines should still be in the garage # but the odd Power Ranger drags the biker name down. Think of the emergency services who will attendand when an accident happens.In contrast to the above, let#s spare a thought for the young men thrown in front of Hitler#s battle-hardened forces and Panzer tanks  years ago at St Valéry-en-Caux.The Argylls did rise again, fighting with distinction through Italy later in the war and in many other battles.But too many young Highlanders# lives were lost and changed forever in their valiant effort to stem the Nazi tide at St Valéry.Lest we forget.

title: letters to the editor june 12 2020
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,I would like to take this opportunity to thank volunteers for all their help and hard work over the lockdown period.Volunteering groups have been amazing and I have personal experience of the support offered by Team Tarbert to enable others to stay safely at home.The volunteers have been compassionate and reassuring and every visit the volunteer has a cheery smile and happy wave.Thank you to all volunteers. You have made a dficult situation so much easier and it is much appreciated.Stay safe stay well.Councillor Anne Horn, Tarbert.Is it possible for the public toilet in Lochgilphead to be opened again soonthe necessary safety measures can be put in place to protect the public and staff I would suggest:I think the toilets should be available soon for the public, but more safety measures such as disinfectant hand spray would be required before they opened.Peter Laing, Lochgilphead.Dear Mr Laing,In order to focus resources on maintaining essential services, protecting frontline staff and ensuring public safety, a number of services have been suspended, including the closure of public conveniences.At this time, we do not have the resources to ensure public conveniences are regularly cleaned and maintained, furthermore we do not wish to encourage those from outlying areas to visit and risk bringing infection to the local area.We will continue to monitor the services and will re-open the public toilets when safe to do so.Sir,In condoning Dominic Cummings decision to go to Durham and Barnard Castle during lockdown, Boris Johnson has completely undermined trust in the UK Government and its efforts to control the spread of the deadly coronavirus.To trivialise his misdemeanours effectively says #it’s alright to disobey the rules#, #just follow your own instincts#. It shows contempt for those in the NHS who have risked their lives to save others. It shows contempt for those who have died without their loved ones by their side. It shows contempt for all of us who have stuck by the rules to protect our lives and the lives of others.Boris Johnson has asked us to #move on# but this issue will not go away. This is a wound that will continue to fester.Dominic Cummings continues to be a major player in government decisions and rules, those rules he so shamelessly flaunted without even an apology. He should have had the humility and integrity to resign, or been sacked by the Prime Minister.Marion Lacey, Lochgair.Sir,Organised by Scottish Land and Estates , the annual Helping it Happen Awards, which are free to enter, showcase the work done in   by businesses, farms and estates to help rural Scotland thrive.We have heard of so many wonderful examples of people working together during the COVID- pandemic, so we are especially encouraging entries to our new #Community Champion of the Year# category.If you have helped your community during the pandemic, ersied your business, are doing innovative work on your farm or perhaps you have been doing some really important work in conservation, the environment or educating youngsters about rural Scotland, you should enter # or nominate someone .The Helping it Happen Awards are sponsored by GLM and there will be a Community Champion of the Year award across five Scottish regions: North East, Highland, Central Scotland, South West and South East.To enter, visit tie SLE website or search for #Helping it Happen Awards# online. The deadline is Wednesday August .Sarah-Jane Laing, chief executive, Scottish Land and Estates.You can be big, you can be small,You can be heroes, one and all.You can be Captain Tom on his hundredth lap,Support key workers with the Thursday night clap,Provide a Care Home with protective gear,Be a voice on the phone dispelling all fear,A musician or singer putting smiles on a face,When out and about respecting other folks’ space,The company boss with a work-safe plan,A volunteer who signs up to help where she can,Raise funds like the wee boy riding his bikeOr run up and down stairs # a dad’s mountain hike,Give a shielding neighbour a friendly wave,Be an ICU nurse with a le to save.The things that you do can be big, can be small,You can be heroes, one and all.Kirstin Thompson, Lochgilphead.
