Key projects for the future of Scotland like the R broadband scheme and the new Sick Kids Hospital in Edinburgh have seen nothing but delay after delay.On the R project, the SNP have broken their promise to extend Scotlandrsquos broadband fibre network, massively letting down rural communities across the country.The SNP Government promised to ldquoensure that  per cent of premises across Scotland have access to super-fast broadband by . However, SNP minister Paul Wheelhouse has admitted work on the network will run well late and past .The new Sick Kids in Edinburgh is now more than a year late in opening due to Scottish Government screw-ups. It was supposed to open last July, but that was delayed at the last minute over concerns for patient safety.A new opening date of August  was announced but that date is also now in doubt.These sorts of failures from the Scottish Government are all too common and Nicola Sturgeon should now match the Prime Ministerrsquos ambition, get Scotland building and finish these vital infrastructure projectswe are not to fall behind the rest of the UK.She has no excuse because thanks to the Prime Ministerrsquos announcement Scotlandrsquos capital budget is up by more than pound. billion.Another project which should be ramped up in speed of delivery, and would give a great boost to not just the East Lothian economy but also the whole Scottish economy, is the expansion of the East Coast Main Line.Locally, getting more local train services running from North Berwick and Dunbar, stopping throughout our county, to Edinburgh would not only create the potential for new jobs and take the strain off currently overburdened rail infrastructure but it would also be better for our environment, reducing the number of car journeys. It would also benefit national economy, as it would also give scope for increasing the number of Edinburgh to London services. That is why I have written to the Transport and Finance Secretaries calling for improvements to be brought forward.The SNP now has the money to kickstart our economy and generate thousands of jobs, including here in East Lothian ndash whether it will or not is up to them.

title: family-make-exciting-marine-discovery-beach-walk
story: Zoe and Colin Hamilton, along with their six-year-old twins Alfie and Millie, werenrsquot sure at first what kind of sea creature they had found during their walk near the Mountjoy area.Zoe said they thought it might be squid eggs, adding: ldquoWe love exploring the beach and there has definitely been a rise in wildle recently ndash lots of jellyfish and starfish too.East Lothianrsquos countryside rangers said they were likely to be the eggs of the common squid, Loligo vulgaris, the adults of which very occasionally get washed up dead on local beaches.Biologist Dr Gavan Cooke, of The Cephalopod Citizen Science Project, has now posted the Hamilton familyrsquos sighting on the grouprsquos Facebook page, saying that the discovery is the furthest north in recent weeks.He said: ldquoWe are seeing many wash up on the shores in the last few weeks and this sighting is the furthest north we have.He added: ldquoI am working with the Centre for Environment, Fisheries and Aquaculture Scienceas we have no fisheries quotas for our cephalopod species, and egg sightings like these are a first step to understanding their reproductive biology, which allows sensible quotas to be formulated.Dr Cooke said: ldquoAfter a male and female mate, the female squid lays eggs. The eggs are laid inside an egg case. So, each long tube has hundreds of eggs.ldquoSince the squid is usually a part of a shoal, it is laid with many other egg cases from many other squids, and then anchored to the sea floor. Butthe seas are rough the eggs can become detached, as we are seeing at the moment.ldquoAlthough the developing embryos may not survive, the species is used to this kind of dficulty and, as such, should not be a major concern conservation wise.ldquoWe know very, very little detail of the species we find in the UKand so sightings like these are of tremendous help to their conservation in the face of intense fishing pressures.ldquoThe best way to get in touch is to join the group and share the observation. Images are useful but not essential.ldquoOld observations, with a date and location are also very valuable.Dr Cooke won a grant to give a talk ndash lsquoWhat Krakens Lie Beneath: A Guide to UK Cephalopodsrsquo ndash but, due to lockdown, this has been postponed until next year.Cephalopods, which include octopus, cuttlefish and nautilus, an ancient animal with a shell, are molluscs, closely related to slugs and snails.A erse group of animals, they have been studied by humans for at least , years.The word cephalopod means lsquohead footrsquo in Greek.Fossils show the extinct species of Ammonites, which died off at the same time as the dinosaurs when an asteroid smashed into the planet, and also Belemnites.Over the centuries they have become creatures of myth in the guise of the kraken ndash a sea monster of gigantic size in Scandinavian folklore ndash with drinks, such as rum, named after the creature.Cephalopods are also popular designs for tattoos.To register a sighting, contact The Cephalopod Citizen Science Project at bit.ly ZKthUjFor more information, search lsquoUK cephalopod reportsrsquo on Facebook.

title: singing-dog-lends-paw-support-community-kitchen
story: Social enterprise Our Community Kitchen has delivered more than , hot meals to people throughout Haddington during the coronavirus crisis.However, it has not just been meals ndash including chicken casserole, tuna pasta bake and corned beef stovies with red cabbage ndash that have been warming hearts and putting smiles on faces.Maria Maguire and her trusty companion Bertie, a soft toy, have also been perking people up during the dficult time.Maria, who trained professionally as an actor and performer, said: ldquoIt all came about because I do laughter therapy and relaxation ways to help cheer people up.ldquoWhen I was starting to do the deliveries, I wore a funny hat and asked peoplethey would like a song.ldquoI would change song and ask for requests.Since then, performances have ranged from Happy Birthday to Old MacDonald Had A Farm, with each commission raising money for the good cause.Our Community Kitchen was formed by Elaine Gale more than two years ago with a view to tackling social isolation throughout Haddington and the surrounding villages.Members of the public were invited to Haddington Bowling Club, where they could enjoy a tasty meal and get round the dinner table with other members of the community.Lockdown restrictions meant the facility had to close its doors but the decision was made to deliver meals to ensure people were still getting fed.Maria has known Elaine for a number of years and describes Our Community Kitchen as ldquoa marvellous idea.However, until recently, Maria, who specialises in complementary therapies, had been unable to volunteer with the group due to work commitments.When lockdown restrictions got under way, she offered to deliver food throughout the town.She said: ldquoOur Community Kitchen was set up to help people with isolation, in whatever shape or form ndash is this not isolation for them ldquoI particularly wanted to help with that.ldquoI always thought that it was a brilliant idea and it had a great number of volunteers, particularly helping with the driving.ldquoNow I am available to help I can do that too.Maria, who lives in the town, said delivering the meals and seeing the reaction on peoplersquos faces was wonderful.At the same time, she has also joined volunteers in making wellness calls and checking in on vulnerable members of the community to ensure they are alright.Elaine said Bertie had proven a great success and was even performing for people on the other side of the world.She said: ldquoPeople across the world are donating to Our Community Kitchen and local people are donating as well.ldquoMaria is going out with him and doing a singsong at peoplersquos doors and it is just wonderful.ldquoIt is cheering everybody up.ldquoIt is a bit of fun in this really confusing time for people, it is just so lovely.

title: avid-golfer-creates-new-bucket-list-courses-book
story: Colin Ramsay, , of The Paddock, hopes that his new publication will inspire people to take up the sport, as well as highlighting the ldquohidden gem courses throughout the country.Called A Golferrsquos Bucket List of Scottish Golf Courses, he said it was primarily a reference book whereby golfers could tick off each course they played on, with space to record their playing partners, scores and memories of the day.Mr Ramsay said the courses highlighted were not just the ldquotrophy courses which many golfers found too expensive to play.He hoped that the book would be a ldquopermanent keepsake for golfers to record courses played, including those in East Lothian, instead of using notebooks or spreadsheets.Mr Ramsay, a member of Kilspindie Golf Club at Aberlady, said: ldquoMany activities have their must-do lists for example, hillwalkers try to lsquobagrsquo all the Munros in Scotland.ldquoI decided that it was time golfers had a similar list and so the idea for this book was born. It details every golf course currently available to play in the nation where the game was invented.ldquoThe book also includes advice to help your game, interesting articles and beautul photographs of courses from across the country.Mr Ramsay started playing golf at the age of  on Craigentinny Golf Course in Edinburgh, which was about  yards from his family home.He joined the club within the course, Lochend Golf Club, as a junior member in . He went on to become junior champion and was a three-time winner of the club championship.He was also a member of Duddingston Golf Club, where he won the junior championship in  and was the beaten finalist in the club championship in .In , Mr Ramsay retired from a career which spanned  years with the Inland Revenue, renamed HM Revenue  Customs.He then spent four years working in the menrsquos locker room at Archerfield Links .In February last year, he sought a fresh challenge and now works as the supervisor in the professionalrsquos shop at Bruntsfield Links Golfing Society in Edinburgh.He is a certied Mind Factor coach, mentored by performance coach Karl Morris, and has set up his own business, Golf Inner Game Coaching.Mr Ramsay said: ldquoMy business is aimed at helping golfers of all ages and standards to achieve their true potential.ldquoIf I can help golfers free up their minds and get out of their own way then golf can become a more enjoyable experience.The bookrsquos foreword has been written by Scottish PGA professional Alan Tait, the course record holder at the championship course at Carnoustie for  years, from  to , with a score of eight under par .He said: ldquoIrsquove been very lucky some four or five decades on, to have played all our lsquotrophy coursesrsquo as well as many hidden gems along the way.ldquoIt goes without saying, we are spoiled in Scotland as golfers.ldquoIt would be nice to look back in a book such as this and remember, in a little more detail, the experience of that day.ldquoEnjoy Colinrsquos book, create your own bucket list and jot down your experiences.Mr Ramsay, who is also a country member at Leven Links Golf Club and Alnmouth Golf Club, is hoping to write similar ldquobucket list books for England, Wales, Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland.A Golferrsquos Bucket List of Scottish Golf Courses, priced pound., has been released on Amazon and Waterstones, plus  online stores worldwide.For more information on Golf Inner Game Coaching go to www.golfinnergamecoaching or email info@golfinnergamecoaching

title: east-beach-restoration-resumes-covid-19-lockdown-eases
story: The coronavirus pandemic halted planned improvement works at the beach the works aimed to help bring sand back while also protecting nearby Lamer Street.Now, as lockdown restrictions are eased, East Lothian Council has confirmed work is once again under way.A spokeswoman for the local authority told the Courier: ldquoThe site reopened last week with required Covid measures put in place.ldquoWorks are now progressing with protection works to the Lamer Street seawall.For a number of years, the beach was a popular tourist attraction due to its golden sands.However, the disappearance of the sand due to coastal erosion coincided with a drop in visitor numbers.Discussions on what could be done to tackle the problem have been ongoing for a number of years. A solution was agreed earlier this year, with hopes that the project would be completed by the summer.The global pandemic has delayed the plans, with no confirmed completion date now in place.The first phase of works will see the construction of a breakwater at the southern end of the beach, with the existing groyne refurbished.Rock armour will also be put in place at the toe of the seawall.Previously, consideration was given to importing sand from where but the idea was dismissed due to the cost and the potential for the sand to simply be washed away.Last year, Councillor Norman Hampshire, who represents the town on East Lothian Council, stressed the importance of the beach to the town.He said: ldquoAnybody that visits the town centre wants to go to the seaside.ldquoYou are on High Street and the harbour is really attractive and you come along to the East Beach and something that does not look attractive at all.ldquoAny successful seaside town needs a sandy beach in the town centre.

title: help-group-get-biplane-air-20-year-campaign
story: Sophie, a Sopwith -  Strutter, is Scotlandrsquos only flying First World War aircraft and was built in a workshop in Congalton, near East Fortune.Aviation Preservation Society Scotland , which built the plane with the help of its volunteers, is encouraging people to adopt a square foot of the plane in a bid to raise pound,, which will help certy the plane and allow it to fly for at least a year.The group has been building the plane using original plans, techniques and aircraft-grade material for the past  years, having been asked to build it by the National Museum of Flight.The group was at the point of testing the engine for the first time when lockdown struck, forcing its workshop to close.Gerard Lohan, APSS member and trustee, said: ldquoWe were planning to invite everyone to her maiden flight around August and from there start doing the major fundraising we need to buy our workshop shed and make it fit for purpose.ldquoThat purpose being to build more aircraft, attract more volunteers and offer training in heritage skills to the community.ldquoI think once it is actually flying and people see it, it will start looking after itself.ldquoBut we just need to get it over the line and up in the air.ldquoThis project has been the focus of these guysrsquo lives for a long time and they keep going.ldquoThis is amazing work they wouldnrsquot have dreamt of doing.On the techniques they used to build the plane, he said: ldquoWe thought that,we were going to do it, we were going to do it properly and by hand like they did at the time.He added that the name Sophie ldquojust sprang to him one day but that the plane is also referred to as ldquobeast or ldquoold girl.If the money cannot be raised to get Sophie in the air, the Aviation Preservation Society may be forced to sell her to a collection in England.Gerard said: ldquoBuilding this aircraft has meant the world to us and we want to share it with the community.ldquoIt has not been as bad as for people who have lost their jobs or whose businesses have closed but [lockdown] was a shame because the sooner we get it into the air, the sooner we are in a position to show it.ldquoIt would be lovely to get it in the air round about now, but now it could be next year.ldquoWe want people to feel like they are part of the plane it is their aeroplane as much as ours. It is totally about the community.He also noted the potential jobs, volunteering opportunities and events, such as re-enactments, that could come to the local community should the money be raised and the plane stay in Scotland.A portion of the money will also go towards improving the grouprsquos workshop, allowing members of the public to visit the plane and it to become a ldquosocial asset in the community.So far, pound, has been raised.To donate, go to localgiving.org charity savesophieFor more information on APSS and its Strutter project, go to www.strutteraviation

title: teacher-says-goodbye-ross-high-40-years
story: Rhona McNaughton called it a day on Friday, June , after spending her entire teaching career at the Tranent secondary school.She thanked pupils past and present, as well as colleagues, for making the job so enjoyable and their well wishes in her retirement.Mrs McNaughton said: ldquoI just really, really hope in the  years I have been at the school that I have had an effect on the community and the way they look at the world as far as geography is concerned.ldquoI want them to know how they are a very special community.ldquoI donrsquot think they realise it but they are a very, very special school.The coronavirus has not only impacted upon her ability to say goodbye but also her retirement plans, with Mrs McNaughton and her husband Martin unable to enjoy a planned trip last week.The mum-of-two added: ldquoMy oldest son, Stephen, has been working in the USA since January.ldquoWe are gutted at not being able to go and see him and we may not be able to get out this year.ldquoThat was part of the plan and I should be in Lisbon today [last Tuesday]. We were supposed to be going away for a few days but one thing we have done is get a puppy eight weeks ago, called Reggie.Initially, Mrs McNaughtonrsquos time at the secondary school was due to be brief.Six weeks leading up to Christmas  was the original plan but she would go on to stay slightly longer!The mum-of-two said: ldquoI started at Ross High when I qualied in .ldquoIt was my very first teaching job.ldquoI was working at the Scotsman offices and got a phone call in late October askingI would come for six weeks.ldquoI started on November , , and was only supposed to be there until Christmas.Plenty would change at the school over the next four decades, with countless pupils and members of staff coming and going.Mrs McNaughton said attitudes had also changed, as when she started she was told she had to wear a skirt.She added: ldquoThere was also a menrsquos staff room, with a pool table, that the females were not allowed in it is quite remarkable.The -year-old finished her career as faculty principal teacher of social subjects.However, she was disappointed she never got a real chance to say goodbye to pupils and staff, with the school having been closed for more than three months due to the coronavirus pandemic.Mrs McNaughton said it took away the best part of the job, which was interacting with the pupils.She said everything felt ldquoa bit stolen from me as she never had the chance to say goodbye to the school.The Edinburgh resident said: ldquoThe worst thing for me were the two days prior to March  when I suddenly realised what was happening.ldquoI knew I had still a term to get myself to terms with what was going to happen.ldquoThe majority of pupils did not know I was going, which I found really hard as I had a good relationship with a lot of them.A retirement party has now been rearranged for January next year with her colleagues, although she did get one early retirement present not long after lockdown started.The diehard Hearts fan, who has had a season ticket at Tynecastle since she was a teenager, was joined in a morning work call by former Jambos captain Gary Locke, who her husband taught at Lasswade High School, and Sky Sports reporter Keith Downie.Mrs McNaughton said: ldquoThe ethos amongst staff and pupils is brilliant, particularly it is a really together staff and it always has been in the time I have been there.ldquoThere are a lot of long-serving members of staff at the school, which shows that.ldquoThe pupils are just great and a really good bunch.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, the local authorityrsquos spokeswoman for education and childrenrsquos services, wished Mrs McNaughton well in her retirement.She said: ldquoI would like to thank Rhona for her  years of service to Ross High School.ldquoShe has given an incredible amount of dedication and commitment to the school.ldquoDuring that time she has inspired and supported thousands of pupils throughout the years.ldquoAs the school regent, she has helped to develop many teachers.ldquoShe will be hugely missed by everyone at the school.ldquoWhat she has left behind is an incredible legacy of her work for which she should be very proud of.

title: bowling-clubs-bid-bar-grey-squirrels-gets-green-light
story: The animals have caused damage at Dirleton Bowling Club, with improvement works to the clubhouse now approved by East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department.Derek Carter, from the bowling club, on the villagersquos Castle Park, told the Courier the intention was for work to start after the outdoor season was complete.He said: ldquoThe programme is really for the winter.ldquoThe next step, quite soon, is to go out for tenders and we have got grants ongoing.A cost for the project is yet to be revealed and Mr Carter said the ongoing coronavirus pandemic ldquocomplicated most things.Covid- restrictions were relaxed towards the end of May, which allowed bowlers to head back to the greens for the outdoor season.However, even so, social distancing restrictions remain in force.The bowling clubrsquos plans will see the building transformed both inside and out.A new kitchen will be created inside the clubhouse, with decorating also being planned.Outdoors, work will be carried out to ensure grey squirrels cannot get inside and cause damage.A design and access statement included within the planning application highlighted the problems the bowling club, which dates back almost  years, was having with the animals.It reads: ldquoThe catalyst for this improvement project is the extensive ongoing damage to the existing clubhouse roof caused by grey squirrels nesting in the roof during the past three winters.ldquoThey penetrate between the pantiles and nest underneath them, gnawing their way through to the clubroom itself.The approved improvements have been backed by Dirleton Village Association, which confirmed that the proposals were well supported within the village.The bowling club, which has about  members, has been part of the village for  years, with the clubhouse and steps to the bowling green added nearly  years ago.The design and access statement also highlighted the importance of the sport to the village.It reads: ldquoIt is the only village sports club providing exercise and social, intergenerational contact through sport, and the only village team representing the Dirleton community.ldquoIf the practical issues set out below mean that the clubhouse becomes unusable, then the club will be unable to compete in the bowling leagues.ldquoThe expectation of visiting teams is now much higher than it used to be, and clubs such as North Berwick, Aberlady, Stenton and Gullane all have new improved facilities.ldquoThe clubhouse is dark and damp, and the roof sarking boards are being damaged and holed by grey squirrels.ldquoThere is no lighting to the path, which is also muddy and slippery because water pours onto it from the adjacent derelict hall owned by the council.Planning permission was given for the replacement of timber window frames, with new windows to be created on the southern side of the building. A new lamppost will be put in place to improve the lighting outside, while the approach path will be resurfaced with gravel.

title: golden-pencaitland-couple-toast-milestone-wedding-anniversary
story: Robert Fraser, also known as Robin, and his we Anne ran the shop on the A in the village for  years.Anne worked in the shop for a number of years before it was bought by her husband.Robert was born in Pencaitland on April , .He went to Pencaitland Primary School and Ross High School, living in the village all his le.He worked as a mechanic at Rossrsquos Garage in Haddington, and Tilhill Forestry, before buying the Pencaitland shop.Anne was born in Gorebridge on January ,  and attended Greenhall High School.As well as the shop, she worked at a factory in Mayfield near Dalkeith, making parts for aeroplanes.The pair met in the Winton Arms, when Anne was there with her friends and Robert entered after a fishing trip with some fish in a basin.They were married on June , , at a registrarsrsquo office on Hunter Square in Edinburgh.Their reception was held in Musselburghrsquos Pittencrieff Hotel, opposite the townrsquos racecourse.After marriage they moved to Spilmersford View, then to Huntlaw Road in Pencaitland.After the birth of their son John in August , they moved to the house Robert was born in, and then went on to Boggs Holdings.Their daughter Mari was born in August  ndash ldquosix years, six days and six hours apart from her brother, Mari joked.Mari now owns and runs the shop, after it was passed on to her by her dad.As well as two children, Anne and Robert have two grandchildren, -year-old Johnathan and -year-old Niamh.The couple are quite a sociable pair and always had their own interests. Robert was heavily involved in Pencaitland Gala Day and Anne used to be a Venture Scout leader.Robert used to donate Christmas trees to Pencaitland Primary School, due to his work the forestry industry.He also dressed up as Santa Claus several times for the school.Both Robert and Anne are now enjoying their retirement.They are keen gardeners, with Anne a member of Haddington Gardening Club.She also helps out in the shop and does the occasional sht.The family plan to celebrate the occasion with a garden party at the couplersquos house at the end of the month and hope to invite their wedding guests.On the day of their anniversary, the family enjoyed a socially distanced visit at the couplersquos house in Boggs Holdings.

title: community-resilience-groups-dunbar-dunpender-haddington-musselburgh-north-berwick
story: From collecting shopping and vital prescriptions to dog walking and simply being there for people, the volunteers are there for residents throughout the coronavirus crisis.Here, we look at fiveof the groups who are giving up their own time to help out.DunbarDunbarRESILIENCE volunteers are reviewing their role as the county moves from the lsquoresponsersquo to the lsquorecoveryrsquo phase.The resilience team in Dunbar has been working hard for several months to ensure vulnerable members of the community get the help they require.However, with lockdown restrictions easing, the need for assistance has decreased.George Robertson, who has been heavily involved in the community resilience team, was pleased with the efforts of all those involved.He told the Courier: ldquoMany of our volunteers will soon be ing to work or may be taking a well-earned break with their families.ldquoIt is clear that East Lothian Council would like some form of volunteer support to continue going forward and we expect some guidance on that in the near future.ldquoThe initial response to our request for volunteers in early March was terric, and we ended up with more on our books than we were able to use.ldquoIt was fortunate that the calls for volunteer service were fewer then we first anticipated, but those who were used were kept busy with their regular customers for shopping, prescriptions and other lsquogood neighbourrsquo services.ldquoAs lockdown began to ease, people were more able and willing to venture out for themselves and even the lsquoshieldedrsquo category will soon be able to resume a more normal le with appropriate safeguards.ldquoMore and more of the local shops are now offering home deliveries, so the calls for our services have reduced.ldquoThe support offered by our volunteers was not all about shopping, and our elderly and isolated customers very much appreciated the social contact which this brought.ldquoWe are now trying to help those who are anxious toto self-sufficiency where possible.However, George stressed the efforts would not simply be stopping immediately.Instead, volunteers will continue to be there for those who need them.He added: ldquoWe are continuing to provide volunteers for foodbank deliveries and for the meals service.ldquoWe work closely with The Ridge in Dunbar, who have been providing help and support to the vulnerable throughout this period.ldquoWhen we do transition to the recovery phase, which is expected to be around August , we will not abandon our charges and will continue to provide a service, albeit with a smaller team.Contact detailsTo contact the Dunbar resilience team, email Dunbar.covid@gmailEast Linton. Picture: Google MapsDunpenderCOMMUNITY councillors hope to host their first meeting in several months in September.Dunpender Community Council, which includes East Linton, Tyninghame and Whitekirk, has been heavily involved in the resilience efforts in the three villages.Judith Priest, chairwoman of the group, said they planned to wind up the resilience efforts at the end of this month, although volunteers were still available to help people.The community council now hopes toto normal business, with a meeting in September.Contact detailsInformation relating to the coronavirus and assistance in the area can be found at www.tyninghamevillagehall.org.uk or www.eastlinton.ukFurther assistance can also be found by calling   or  .HaddingtonHaddingtonRESILIENCE volunteers will be on hand to helpthere is a second wave of the coronavirus.A squad of volunteers has been working hard in Haddington since lockdown restrictions were introduced in March.However, the group plans to wind up at the end of this month.Chris McEwan, who has been leading the community resilience efforts in the town, said the group continued to get fewer and fewer calls.He stressed that assistance would be availablerestrictions were reintroduced but he was hopeful the volunteers would play more of a secondary role to East Lothian Council.He said: ldquoWe would expect that the council will have a little bit more of a robust plan. ldquoThey have had enough time to plan for it.ldquoWe are meant to be there to assist them in the short term but we have been doing it for four months.ldquoThe whole resilience team idea was to be there to help during bad weather or snow storms.ldquoWe were not really designed to do what we did but all the single points of contact stood up and helped where we could and did what we could.Chris, who is also vicechairman of the townrsquos community council, said there had been fewer than half a dozen calls to them in the past week, with those calls relating to the collection of prescriptions.One of the other services offered by the resilience group is a lending library, which offers a loan of books, games and jigsaws.Chris said the group had taken the decision to not offer DVDs, which had instead been sold to an internet site and the money reinvested in the lending library.Contact detailsAnyone needing assistance can call   between am and pm.Further information surrounding the coronavirus and the help on offer is available from the community councilrsquos website, www.haddingtoncc.org.ukMusselburgh. Picture: Google MapsMusselburghA FAMILY has praised Resilient Musselburgh for the ldquowarm welcome to their new home in the town.Owain Evans, his we Mary, their son Reuben, , and daughter Savannah Rose, aged seven, moved from Tanzania in East Africa to the Honest Toun recently, after a few weeksrsquo quarantine.Their first priority was to buy a copy of the Courier, where they saw an article about the Musselburgh Tool Library, which has supported Resilient Musselburghrsquos efforts during the Covid- pandemic.Owain said he called Resilient Musselburgh as they were in need of some tools but were delighted to also receive colouring books and chocolates for their children as an added bonus.Owain said: ldquoWhat a warm welcome to our new home ndash we were really touched.He explained: ldquoWhat was tricky was being out in Tanzania teaching and all the flights were cancelled for months.ldquoWe didnrsquot know how or when wersquod be able to leave. That was a little stressful but in the end the UK put on a special emergency repatriation flight that we managed to get onto.The family are now settling into their new home on High Street, where they are involved in creating a communal garden at the back of the building.Owain has now become a volunteer with Resilient Musselburgh, helping to deliver copies of the Courier to vulnerable local residents in the community.Iain Clark, chairman of Musselburgh Area Partnership, paid tribute to the volunteers and those who have donated goods and funds during the pandemic.He said: ldquoA big thank you to First Step Community Project for their financial donation, and Resilient Musselburgh really appreciated the delivery of  new books organised by Councillor Andy Forrest through BaxterStorey, GS and Royal Bank of Scotland, sourced from the Scottish Book Trust.ldquoThese will help alleviate isolation and loneliness at this time for many in the community.Contact detailsTo get in touch with Resilient Musselburgh, call  .North Berwick.William Starkey and licensed for reuse under this Creative Commons Licence.North BerwickTHE North Berwick Community Emergency Resilienceteam is preparing to stand down at the end of the month after almost four months of providing help and support to hundreds of people across the community.Judy Lockhart, North Berwick Community Council chairwoman, said people throughout North Berwick had responded magnicently to the challenges of Covid-.She said: ldquoThe community response has been inspiring.ldquoIniduals, clubs, businesses and organisations have all given support and helped each other through.ldquoThe CER team plugged gaps services couldnrsquot fill, so vulnerable people in North Berwick got food, prescriptions and felt part of the community.Sue Northrop, who holds responsibility for the community councilrsquos emergency plan, said the team was planning a phased exit and had set up a small transition group to ensure that people who might need extra help after lockdown were supported and connected to the community.She said: ldquoThe CER team is proposing the town retains much of the capacity developed to meet the emergency on an ongoing basis, not just future Covid- spikes and future emergencies, but as a resource for the whole community and the many groups and charities in the town.These include:The CER team is also working with East Lothian Council and local organisations to prepare for any future emergency.It is holding a series of online events and a short survey to get experiences and views about Covid- across the community.These will be used to develop a new community emergency response plan for a new team to take over.There is awebinarbeing held on Saturdayat am.For the webinar, register at bit.ly ZYnITo take part in the online survey on lsquoNorth Berwick and Covid-: Sharing Experiences and Viewsrsquo, go to www.surveymonkey r DRXYHWMeanwhile, the team is providing free face coverings for those who need them.People can collect them from the community centre on Fridays between am and noon.Contact detailsAs usual,residents need help with shopping or prescriptions they can go to title: buy-scottish-island-iconic-loch-lomond-inchconnachan-island-goes-sale
story: Now, those enjoying the solitude can take their privacy one step further with an entirely private Scottish island all to themselves.An island off the western shore of southern Loch Lomond is to be launched on the market, boasting private, secluded bays and ancient woodland.Inchconnachanhas been in the ownership of the Colquhoun family since the th century but uninhabited for the last  years.Now, it is set to go on the market for offers of more than pound,.The island is only accessible by boat from the shores of Luss, andis home to some of the best wildle the country has to offer.Inchconnachanrsquos ancient oak woodland and secluded bays attract otters and deer, along with a wide iety of birds including the endangered capercaillie and the occasional pair of nesting ospreys.The island is both an Area of Special Scientic Interest and a Special Area of Conservation as well as being part of the Loch Lomond and the Trossachs National Park.Surrounded by a beautul backdrop of mountain ranges, including Ben Lomond, the island currently home to a derelict Colonial-style timber bungalow dating from the s, reputedly built by retired tea merchant, Admiral Sullivan in the style of an Indian tea plantation bungalow.Butyou want a little more luxury, planning consent and detailed architectural drawings have been obtained to replace the existing bungalow with a new four-bedroom lodge and one-bedroom wardenrsquos house, along with a boathouse and pier.Cameron Ewer for Savills said: ldquoThis is an extraordinary opportunity to acquire a beautul and completely private, yet accessible, retreat and create a wonderful new residence there. For those seeking peace and seclusion, yet wanting all that this part of Scotland has to offer in the way of nature and water-based sport and activities, this is surely the ultimate prize.Tom Stewart-Moore for Knight Frank said: ldquoTo be able to build your own house on your own private island but yet in a very accessible and beautul part of the country will be a dream for many and is likely to have global appeal.

title: pop-up-beer-garden-approved-pub-car-park
story: The Green in Haddingtonhad already been granted a temporary licence to serve alcohol from their car park from tomorrowfor  days by licensing officers.But an application for a second lsquooccasionalrsquo licence, which usually only lasts for two weeks, went before East Lothian Licensing Board for approval after local residents lodged objections.And board members expressed their own concerns about the plans, which will see customers served food on the other side of the road from the pub itself.At a meeting of the licensing board, via Skype, police and the councilrsquos own licensing standards officer said they were satisfied with the plans made by applicant Laura McSweeney to safeguard customers and staff while opening the garden.They revealed that the beer garden would operate four days a week with security fencing, a food truck serving table service drinks in the car park and staff bringing food from the pub to a safe table in the garden for collection.All tables will be pre-booked and staff will keep a key to toilet facilities on them and escort any customer who needs to use them across the road and into the building.Police Scotland told the board that concerns had been raised about the road which runs between the puband the pop-up beer garden, which is classed as an lsquoArsquo road and near a junction.However, their representative told the board that they were satisfied with measures taken by Ms McSweeney and her partner to tackle concerns.Councillor Jim Goodfellow, board member, said: ldquoIf someone had shown me this application three months ago I would not have imagined any circumstances in which it would be a possibility.ldquoHowever, we have our officers and the police supporting this and saying with extra conditions it is possible, so I find myself reluctantly supporting it.His views were echoed by Councillor Lachlan Bruce, fellow board member, who added: ldquoThis is an unusual time, the plan is not risk averse, nothing is, but it has been well thought through.However, Councillor Jane Henderson told her board colleagues she could not back the application.She said: ldquoI cannot get comfortable with it, I am not reassured by the measures in place. I think this is too complicated and even in these extraordinary times I would not be happy to grant this application.The board voted by three to one to approve the two-week licence which will run from July  to July , with Councillor Fiona Dugdale, chair, also supporting it.The board was told that an application for a third occasional licence for the first two weeks of August from The Green had been received in the post.

title: rules-jet2-passengers-must-follow-holidays-restart
story: New rules in place for passengersPassengers will be asked to access the Jet app, check-in online and download their boarding pass before arriving at the airport.Although the airline is still allowing up to kg of hand luggage, they are asking customers to pack as light as possible.Masks need to be worn by those aged six and over. These should be put on prior to entering the airport and kept on throughout the journey. However, face coverings such as scarves, snoods and balaclavas are not considered acceptable by Jet.Travellers can either drop bags off with a member of staff or use the one-touch self service kiosks.Boarding is now being done in small groups when at the gate, in order to allow for social distancing. Customers are asked to scan their own boarding passes and then show their passports to the flight attendants.On board the plane, food and duty-free items are still being sold, but customers are asked to use contactless payments wherever possible.There wont be any hand sanitiser onboard any of Jetrsquos planes, so passengers are encouraged to bring their own - but make sure its less than ml.Toilets will be open to use as normal, but passengers are being asked to wait safely in their seat until one is free to avoid queuing in the aisles.All planes are cleaned daily and fogged with disinfectant spray, according to Jet.The Foreign and Commonwealth Officerecently updated its global advisory against lsquoall but essentialrsquo travel, which exempts some destinations that ldquono longer pose an unacceptably high risk for British travellers.These exemptions came into effect on  July, but all of the FCOrsquos advice will remain under constant review in order to take into account the latest situation in each country.The FCO explains that ldquothese countries have been assessed as no longer presenting an unacceptably high risk to British people travelling abroad.The Department for Transport has also issued a list of countries that travellers can visit, without having to self-isolate on theirto England. This comes into effect on  July.

title: public-toilets-start-reopen
story: East Lothian Council will begin opening a limited number of public toilets this weekend,with disabled facilities the first to come back into use.The council said the disabled access facilities at its public loos would be available for use between am and pm from tomorrow , at a number of sites.The sites include: Aberlady Bay Nature ReserveYellowcraig BeachBayswell Road, Dunbar John Muir Country ParkShore Road, DunbarSkateraw Beach, Dunbar Gullane BentsLongniddry Bents car parks  and Fisherrow Harbour, MusselburghQuality Street, North BerwickLinks Road, Port SetonAyres Wynd, PrestonpansWhitesands Beach, DunbarNeilson Park Road, Haddington andShorthope Street, Musselburgh.A number of changes have been introduced by the council to help keep people safe, including a limit on the number of people in a toilet building at one time with the opening of the disabled access facilities only which provides a lsquoone in, one outrsquo system.Councillor Norman Hampshire, depute council leader, said: ldquoWe will be opening our public toilets in a phased approach over the coming weeks to make sure both the public and staffare kept safe.ldquoWe know that this will be very welcome news not just to visitors but local residents who for health reasons, or with young families, rely on access to public toilets to be able to leave their homes.ldquoAs only the single occupant disabled toilets are opening at this stage, we would like to advise visitors to please acknowledge priority use for people with disabilities.ldquoWith current physical distancing guidelines still in place, we cannot reopen the larger toilet facilities at this time.ldquoThis is to maintain good hygiene standards and to minimise any potential spread of infection.ldquoWersquore asking visitors and local residents to respect the facilities, which will be subject to daily checks and cleaning regimes in line with current Scottish Government guidelines.

title: covid-19-postpones-scottish-half-marathon
story: It was initially scheduled to take place on September , but organisers took the decision this morningto postpone the event until next year.In a statement, a spokesperson said: ldquoOver the past four months we have been working closely with, and drawing on the vast array of knowledge and resources available from, the UK and Scottish Governments, World Athletics, local authorities teams and medical teams to research, plan and work to adapt our delivery models.ldquoThis was to ensure that,government restrictions allowed, we were able to deliver a safe event.ldquoIt is with deep regret however, that we have taken the very dficult decision to postpone the event until . We think that itrsquos important that you understand how and why we have come to make this decision.ldquoAs you know, it is outside of our control to say when events will be permitted to go ahead, and sadly there is insufficient information currently available to allow us to estimate when this will be.ldquoThe nature of the event demands a considerable amount of preparation, not only from our team and our delivery partners, but from the participants.ldquoTheir preparation for an event will involve training, sometimes meaning they are dedicating many hours away from their friends and family, which for many is understandably unpalatable or impossible with the demands of home working, childcare and schooling at this time.ldquoFor others it requires the booking of accommodation or travel and we feel that it is unfair to ask for your and their continuing preparationwe cannot make a firm assurance that we will definitely be able to go ahead with the event on the planned date.ldquoWe, as a team, are devastated to be sharing this announcement with you. We know you will be equally disappointed and we are acutely aware of the impact that the loss of events is having on our affiliate charities. We will continue to do everything we can to support them.Those due to take part in the run this year are asked to log into their account on the Scottish Half Marathon website and select their preferred option before September .If people take no action before the deadline, their entry will be automatically deferred to next yearrsquos run, which takes place on September .The route starts at Meadowmill Sports Centre takes people through Longniddry, Port Seton, Cockenzie, Prestonpans and ends at Musselburgh Racecourse.For more information visit www.scottishhalfmarathon

title: hairdressers-scotland-reopen-week----changes-expect
story: Speaking in the Scottish Parliament on Thursday, the First Minister confirmed a number of lockdown measures would be eased across the country as we moved into Phase .She suggested that becuase of the drastic nature of the recent changes, it could be some time until we reach the final phase of the four-part route map out of lockdown.Among the eagerly anticipated dates announced for reopening - which generated laughter in Parliament - is that of hairdressers and barbers.Nicola Sturgeon confirmed this isfrom July .Personal retail services such as beauticians and tailors can reopen with enhanced hygiene measures can also reopen from July .Here, we outline some of the changes that will likely face you at the hairdressers:What changes will there be inside The British Beauty Council has outlined a number of suggested guidelines for social distancing and hygiene within hairdressers and salons.They suggest, among other advice, the following:Will I have to wear a mask According to the British Beauty Council, clients are to ldquobring their own PPE unless employers decide to supply.Currently, it looks like it will be a matter for each inidual salon to decide ndash but going on that advice it is probable you will have to wear a face covering.What  might change Some hairdressers may opt to extend their opening hours ndash meaning staff can see clients but have less people inside at any one time.As with supermarkets, the British Beauty Council recommends a ldquovulnerable hour first thing, once the salon has been deep cleaned from the previous day.It may also be harder to get an appointment, with extreme demand following lockdown and the need for an extra  minutes to be allocated for cleaning between clients.Many places will only allow pre-bookings, not walk-ins, and advance payments over the phone would be encouraged.Indoor waiting areas could also be scrapped, with customers having to wait outside until being called in at the time of their appointment.Will it cost more As expected, this might be the case.A note on the British Beauty Council website reads: ldquoIt may be advisable to raise prices to cover cost of PPE, longer opening hours, sanitisation and hygiene equipment, reduced appointments and other accrued costs as a result of COVID-.

title: joy-scottish-bookmakers-scottish-government-agrees-lift-restrictions-betting-shops
story: The shops were allowed to reopen their doors onJune  for the first time since the COVID- lockdown.But unlike in the rest of the UK, the shops were ordered to remove all of their chairs, switch off their gaming machines and not show any live racing on TV. chief executive Michael Dugher " alt"East Lothian Courier: Betting and Gaming Councilchief executive Michael Dugher " class"editor-image"Betting and Gaming Councilchief executive Michael Dugher As a result, turnover in some shops slumped by  per cent as customers either stayed away or crossed the border to England to put on a bet.Industry bosses warned that unless the restrictions were lted, shops could be forced to close and staff made redundant.Following a campaign by the Betting and Gaming Council, it has now been confirmed that from July , the restrictions will no longer apply.However, the shops will still follow strict anti-COVID measures, with customers being encouraged to apply sanitiser and follow social-distancing rules.BGC chief executive Michael Dugher said: ldquoThis is great news for Scotlandrsquos  betting shops and the , hardworking staff that they employ.ldquoWe have always said that the extra restrictions imposed on Scottish betting shops were unnecessary."We are delighted that the Scottish Government has listened and responded.ldquoBetting shops in Scotland can now look forward to playing their part in helping to kickstart the economy, supporting Scottish racing and providing a safe environment for customers who enjoy a flutter.

title: wetherspoons-slashes-pint-prices-1-29-reduces-cost-meals
story: The cuts were announced last week by the Chancellor Rishi Sunak in an attempt to ease economic pressures on the hospitality sector caused by the coronavirus pandemic and lockdown.VAT for the hospitality sector was cut from  per cent to five per cent, and Wetherspoons, who has a venue in Musselburgh, has said that it will pass the savings directly on to customers.Menus featuring a grinning Chancellor alongside messages labelled Sunaks specials and Dishi Rishi boast cut-price deals on food and drink with a pint of beer costing as little as pound..When will the deals start The deals will come into force from Wednesday, July , with real ale, coffee, soft drinks, breakfasts and other food among the discounted items.The VAT cut doesnrsquot apply to alcohol, but Wetherspoon has said it will cut the price of ales in reaction to savings made where.A pint of Ruddles Bitter now costs just pound., down from its pre-cut price of pound., while the price of a pint of Doom Bar has been slashed from pound. to pound..A traditional breakfast will cost pound. - a saving of p. A burger and soft drink is down to pound..Soft drinks will be cut by p, down to pound. for a oz glass.The deals will be in place at  of its pubs.Prices for real ale will be up to pound higher at the companyrsquos other  pubs across the UK which are located in major town and city centres, airports and stations.However, these pubs will have price reductions of at least  pence per drink and  pence per meal.What have Wetherspoons said Wetherspoon chairman Tim Martin called on the move to be made permanently.He said:"Wetherspoon has campaigned for tax equality between pubs, restaurants and supermarkets for many years. Supermarkets pay no VAT on food sales and pubs pay  per cent."Supermarkets pay about two pence per pint of business rates and pubs pay about  pence."These tax dferences have helped supermarkets to subsidise their selling prices of beer, wine and spirits, enabling them to capture about half of pubs beer sales, for example, in the past  years."A VAT reduction will help pubs and restaurants reverse this trend - creating more jobs, helping high streets and eventually generating more tax income for the Government."lsquoNeverspoonsrsquo appWetherspoons has been widely criticised during the coronavirus pandemic, particularly for Tim Martinrsquos actions regarding furloughing staff. title: three-simple-tips-stop-glasses-fogging-wearing-face-masks
story: Last week, the Scottish Government made it a legal requirement to wear coverings in shops - making the use of them a lot more widespread.It comes following the decision to make them mandatory on public transport - with the First Minister saying there has been "close to%" compliance with the new rules.But a number of Scots have been struggling to manage the masks, stating it causes their glasses to steam or fog up.Canny believe a need to pick between breathing or seeing pic VxpHumCgFollowing the latest move,Gordon Kyle fromof Miller and McClure Opticians in Paisley, shared his three top tips to avoid steaming up your lenses.He said: "Ive seen it a lot where peoples glasses are fogging up, there are a few things to think about".Here are the three tips:Mask behind glassesGordon suggests keeping the glasses on top of the mask, which acts almost as a seal keeping the mask tight to the top of the cheeks without pushing air towards the lenses.Tissue paperThe optician suggested lining the top of the mask with tissue paper before putting it on. In his video, this almost completely stops any fog taking place.Tie a knotGordons third tip was to tie the mask on the string so it sits "almost like a package". By doing this, the mask sits in a nicer shape where the air is being pushed away from the glasses.What  The optician joked that anyone with contact lenses should consider using them.Speaking to the Daily Record he also advised against lining the lenses with household items, as seen online.He said:ldquoThere has been chatonlineabout using shaving foam, toothpaste and even methylated spirits but my concern is that it could cause long term damage to the lenses.ldquoThe other thing folk have mentioned for the lenses is washing up liquid. Irsquom just not convinced that itrsquos risk free."

title: town-centre-changes-go-ahead-north-berwick
story: East Lothian Council said public notices will go up tomorrowinforming residents and traders of plans to suspend parking on High Street for four hours on Thursday evening as works starts on its Spaces for People programme.The announcement comes less than a week after the local authority put plans to introducing parking restrictions in town centrs across the county on hold after they sparked an outcry from some traders.The council said that following a meeting with North Berwick Community Council and Coastal Area Partnership and town traders an agreement had been reached to introduce a number of temporary measures in the town, providing extra space for physical distancing to protect public health and suppress a resurgence of Covid-.Councillor Norman Hampshire, deputy council leader and environment spokesman said: "The work will focus on the narrow eastern section of North Berwick High Street and will provide the temporary widening of foothpaths to allow people walking, pushing prams or buggies or using wheelchairs to have sufficient space to observe the current m physical distancing guidelines."Some parking will be removed but a section will remain for local business use to support traders. In addition a combination of bollards and attractive planters will be introduced to narrow the road, reducing vehicle speeds and maximising pedestrian spaceldquoTo balance the need of businesses and supporting the local economy, parking provision within the town will be temporarily amended to provide spaces recognising in particular those with mobility needs."Additional Blue Badge spaces will be provided in Quality Street and Law Road car parks. We will also convert part of Elcho Green to a temporary car park to support access to the High Street area.High Street will be closed to through traffic and parking from .pm tomorrowevening until .pm.The work will be carried out in the following phases:Phase  ndash East End of High Street - Thursday, July ,  from . to .pm to place demarcation bollards and road markings to allow authorised vehicles only to park. Erection of signs re-designating Law Road car park to  minutes and St Andrew Street to  minutes with no .Open Elcho Green to long stay car parking Friday, July  . Barriers and cones to be placed to guide cars parking. Temporary signing of car parks to be erected.Phase  ndash High Street w c Monday, July ,all day rolling programme to conclude the introduction of demarcation bollards and changes to road marking and placement of signs including all link streets except Law road. Disabled bays to be marked out.Phase  ndash One way system from week commencing Monday, July  will mean temporary road works and localised disruption. Road marking and signage to make one way system including demarcation bollards on Law Road. Erection of timeplates to enforce restrictions.Phase  ndash Evening road closure High Street from week commencing Monday, August  to allow for placement of prefabricated speed cushions on High Street and the siting of a speed reactive sign.Application of rolling grasscrete system to protect Elcho Green.

title: Opinion  Marianne Taylor  We   re all public health guinea pigs now    but that   s just the way it has to be
story: Irsquove also started planning a wee holiday up north and have booked a hairdressersrsquo appointment. Irsquove looked out my monthly cinema pass in anticipation of re-opening around July .I appreciate not everyone feels this way, but Irsquom ready to start living again. Irsquom also ready to accept some fundamental political realities.Letrsquos face it, wersquore all just guinea pigs now, part of a radical public health experiment the likes of which has never been attempted before. This experiment is reaching its most dficult phase yet, the bit where the Government has to somehow let people start doing normal things ndash like going back to work and spending money to keep the economy going ndash while simultaneously reminding us that we wersquore not out of the woods yet. They have to encourage people to go out, while keeping them scared.Many ndash including me ndash have criticised politicians for their missteps and mixed messages over the last few months. But I also recognise a number of basic truths that itrsquos better to get onersquos head around sooner rather than later, regardless of party politics.The first is that until coronavirus has been completely eradicated around the world, risk is going to play a part in our lives for the foreseeable future. The second is closely related: the state cannot tell us exactly how to manage this risk in every single circumstance. We may get health advice and government guidance, but ultimately we have to navigate this new, more precarious world on our own.How we do this, and, crucially, how we feel about doing it, depends on many dferent things, of course, not least our age and underlying health, our financial situation and, to a signicant extent, our personality.I know there are some who believe that through lting lockdown restrictions politicians in Westminster and Holyrood are very deliberately handing over responsibility ndash and thus blame ndash to the public for what comes next. And there may be some truth to this. But come on, letrsquos get real.Accusations of ldquomaking it up as they go along are thrown around asthis was an insult rather than simply a fact describing the predicament governments everywhere find themselves in. How could it be otherwise given the extraordinary events of the last six months  And whatrsquos the alternative to us being public health guinea pigs  Staying at home forever Community levels of the virus in Scotland are now low and falling. Our hospitals lie empty. We have a test and trace system in place to ndash hopefully ndash crack down on infections. Meanwhile, wellbeing continues to suffer under the restrictions and hundreds of thousands of jobs hang in the balance. All of these things mean we can and should lt the lockdown. And lting restrictions means the vast majority of folkmust decide for themselves what level of risk they are comfortable contending with, taking into consideration how it might affect their family and community as well as their own personal circumstances.We can help ourselves along the way. Firstly by staying up to date ndash through trusted, legitimate scientic and public information sources ndash about how the virus is transmitted and the best ways to stay safe.We can also resist the temptation to judge others for their decisions. Frankly, Irsquom sick of the army of armchair virologists spouting their culture war vitriol on social media. On one side you have those who seem to relish the lockdown, the class swots who shout too loudly about how they follow every part of the guidanceand seem to revel in the idea of a second wave. On the other side, you have the virus deniers. Both groups peddle fear and misinformation, whether that is their intention or not.At the end of the day none of us, not even the scientists, know whether and when there will be another wave of the virus. Uncertainty permeates through every part of our lives now, and we must find ways to live with and even embrace thiswe are to make it through the tough months ahead. title: paperbacks-name-passionate-spirit-emperors-deep
story: Lemn SissayCanongate, pound.Hersquos now an admired poet, playwright and Chancellor of Manchester University. But, as a boy, Lemn Sissay was condemned to a marginal existence that denied him his heritage and badly affected his mental health. Separated from his Ethiopian mother at a Wigan home for unmarried mothers in , he was renamed Norman and placed with a white foster family. Bullying at school and an oppressive brand of Christianity at home led to his removal to the first of several childrenrsquos homes when he was , unaware that his mother had been pleading for him to be ed to her. Sissayrsquos memories of the harsh, loveless regimes are accompanied by their reports on him, obtained after a -year battle with Wigan Council. A damning indictment of a system that frequently fails young people, this is a heartbreaking and eloquent memoir providing insight into the forces that shaped Sissay into the poet he is today.Emperors of the DeepWilliam McKeeverHarperOne, pound.Sharks. Theyrsquore regarded first and foremost as the most iconic predators of the natural world. But William McKeever wants to downplay their reputation as the ultimate killing machines and focus instead on the role they play in ldquomaintaining the health of the worldrsquos oceans, in the hope that greater appreciation will help protect the creatures and, ultimately, the sea. Reading McKeeverrsquos book, one comes to understand that being an apex predator is like being a custodian of the ocean. Sharks are essential to keeping their ecosystems balanced and maintaining greater bioersity. As well as travelling as far afield as Cape Cod and Australia to study the animals themselves, McKeever investigates the commercial and recreational fishing industry that kills a staggering  million of them a year. Like its subject, Emperors of the Deep is awe-inspiring and terrying in equal measure, but itrsquos the carnage inflicted by humans that prompts the greatest terror.Passionate SpiritCate HasteBloomsbury, pound.Dying in New York in  at the age of , Alma Mahler had not only been married to Gustav Mahler, but also Walter Gropius and after that the less celebrated but still respectably prestigious author Franz Werfel. Growing up in Secession-era Vienna, surrounded by culture and artists from an early age, she was drawn to creative, artistic men, and has often been disparaged as a gold-digger or groupie, or more kindly as a muse. Here, biographer Cate Haste tries to even the score a little, drawing attention to Almarsquos abilities as an accomplished pianist, with a particular affinity for Wagner, who wrote her own music ndash of which, sadly, little survives. Itrsquos not a complete rehabilitation of this ldquopassionate spirit. Her ambition, self-absorption, indiscretion and anti-Semitism are all undeniable. But although no angel, she makes a compelling subject for a vibrant biography: a charismatic, indefatigable woman living through an exciting and turbulent era.

title: recipe-gary-townsends-bulgur-wheat-summer-salad
story: This really does look and taste like summer on a plate. This is a versatile salad and can be served with grilled fish or chicken or as a side at a barbecue. Cooking the cucumber and peppers lts the flavours and adds an interesting dimension.Ingredients - Makes  +g bulgur wheat ndash cooked x g chickpeas x pepperfrac cucumberBaby tomatoesOlivesfrac avocadoHandful of chopped parsleyMint leavesSalt  black pepperVinaigretteml olive oil x lemons charred + zest  juice x garlic cloves ndash crushedfrac tsp Dijon mustard tsp sugarMethodFor the vinaigrette you will need to remove the zest from the lemons. Mix this into the olive oil.Slice the lemons in half and place into a hot pan. Cook on the flat side until a beautul charred colour.Allow these to cool slightly before squeezing the juice into the olive oil along with the rest of the lemon.Add the crushed garlic, mustard and sugar, slightly whisk and allow to sit for around an hour to infuse. Pass off through a sieve and keep until ready to use.For the salad cook the bulgur wheat, once cooked refresh in cold water and allow to drain. Roughly chop the peppers and cucumber and fry off in a pan with a small amount of oil until nicely coloured, add the tomatoes just at the end. Allow to drain on kitchen towel.Chop the avocadoalong with the parsley and mint.Rinse off the chickpeas, place in a large bowl and combine everything. Add the olives, season with salt and black pepper.Drizzle over a generous amount of your vinaigrette and serve.

title: recipe-mary-continis-roasted-herring-new-potato-salad
story: For me, these are an lsquoimpulsersquo buy. If I see them spanking fresh, I canrsquot resist.
